أحمد بوسطيلة |image = |office = |deputy = |term_start = |term_end = |predecessor = |successor = |office1 = Commander of the National Gendarmerie of Algeria |term_start1 = 5 July 2000 |term_end1 = 10 September 2015 |predecessor1 = [[Taïyeb Derradji]] |successor1 = [[Menad Nouba]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1944|08|08|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Aïn M'lila]], [[Algeria]] |death_date = {{death date and age |2018|10|14|1944|08|08|df=y}}[https://www.alg24.net/photos-general-ahmed-boustila-inhume-a-alger/ Le général Ahmed Boustila inhumé à Alger] {{fr icon}} |death_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] |religion = [[Sunni Islam]] |allegiance = {{flag|Algeria}} |branch = [[Gendarmerie Nationale (Algeria)|National Gendarmerie]] |unit = |serviceyears = 1962-2015 |rank = [[Lieutenant general|Général de corps d'armée]]"فريق" |commands = Commander of the National Gendarmerie of Algeria |battles = |awards = }} Major-General '''Ahmed Bousteila''' ({{lang-ar|أحمد بوسطيلة}}) was the former commander of the [[Gendarmerie Nationale (Algeria)|National Gendarmerie]] of [[Algeria]].{{cite web|url=http://www.anp.org/fiche/fiche.html|accessdate=2010-11-09|title=ANP ALGERIE, FICHIER|date=2010-09-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101119102803/http://anp.org/fiche/fiche.html| archivedate= 19 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} from the 5 July 2000 until the 10 of September 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.aps.dz/en/algeria/8549-installation-of-major-general-menad-nouba-as-commander-of-national-gendarmerie|accessdate=2015-09-13|title=Algeria Press Service - Installation of Major General Menad Nouba as commander of National Gendarmerie}} ==Early life and career== Bousteila Bousteila was born in [[Aïn M'lila]]in [[Oum el-Bouaghi]] on 8 April 1944,{{cite web|url=http://www.menas.co.uk/documents/Algeria's%20Perfect%20Storm%20-%20Jeremy%20Keenan%20-%20Menas%20Associates%20-%2031.03.10.pdf |accessdate=2010-11-09 |title=Algeria's Perfect Storm }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and it is suggested that he may take the helm at the ministry of defence. He joined the FLN Army as a Conscript in 1962 during the final stages of the War of Independence, and after Independence moved up the ranks to secure a commission from the Military Academy. He was commissioned into the Army Signal Corps in 1965 and transferred to the Gendarmerie in 1969. He was trained in Intelligence work in the Soviet Union. In 1991 he was promoted to Brigadier General and Commander of the 12th Gendarmerie Brigade. In 1996 he was promoted to Major General and Commander of the 2nd Security Division i.e. covering all Gendarmerie Divisions in North-Western Algeria.{{cite web|url=http://www.africaintelligence.fr/MC-/who-s-who/2006/03/23/ahmed-boustila%2C18501838-BRE-login|accessdate=2010-11-09|title=Ahmed Bousteila - Algerie - Maghreb Confidentiel}} he was promoted to [[Lieutenant general]] rank on 5 July 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffpostmaghreb.com/2015/09/10/bousteila-nouba-gendarmer_n_8118118.html|accessdate=2015-09-13|title=huffpostmaghreb Algerie - Le général-major Menad Nouba nouveau chef de la gendarmerie, Ahmed Bousteila à la retraite}} He was involved in the Algerian government's rollout of [[biometric passport]]s and also ordered increased security measures on roads.{{cite web|url=http://www.echoroukonline.com/eng/index.php?news=11092|accessdate=2010-11-09|title=Echorouk Online - Algeria mobilises 40,000 gendarmes to secure East-West Motorway}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boustila, Ahmed}} [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:People from Oum El Bouaghi Province]] [[Category:Algerian people]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Algerian military personnel]] [[Category:Algerian generals]]

'''Anthony King''' is an American writer, [[Theatre director|director]], and comedian based in [[Los Angeles]]. He was previously the [[Artistic Director]] of the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]] in [[New York City]][https://web.archive.org/web/20080227214942/http://newyork.ucbtheatre.com/performers/1560]. King attended the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|University of North Carolina]] in [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina]].
King wrote the [[off-Broadway]] musical ''[[Gutenberg! The Musical!]]'' with Scott Brown [https://web.archive.org/web/20080526073134/http://gutenbergthemusical.com/cast-creative.html]. He was nominated for an [[Emmy]] in 2011 for "Outstanding Writing For A Variety, Music Or Comedy Special" for "Night Of Too Many Stars: An Overbooked Benefit For Autism Education" [http://www.comedycentral.com/shows/night_of_too_many_stars/index.jhtml] which aired on [[Comedy Central]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Primetime Emmy Award Nominations 2011|url=http://www.emmys.com/nominations/2011/Outstanding%20Writing%20For%20A%20Variety,%20Music%20Or%20Comedy%20Special|accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref>

Cruz]], [[Manila]], Philippines | birth_name= April Love Antolo Jordan | height={{height|ft=5|in=9}} | eye_color= Brown | hair_color= Black }} '''April Love Antolo Jordan''' (born April 10, 1988) is a Filipino beauty queen and fashion model. She is one of the 25 candidates competing to become [[Miss World Philippines 2012]].{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/45021/ph-eyes-hosting-rights-for-miss-world-2015 |title=PH eyes hosting rights for Miss World 2015 | Inquirer Entertainment |publisher=Entertainment.inquirer.net |date=2012-06-14 |accessdate=2012-06-18}} ==Life and education== Jordan was born on April 10, 1988, in [[Sta. Cruz, Manila|Sta. Cruz]], [[Manila]] as the eldest child of entrepreneurs Eugene Jordan and Imelda Antolo. She grew up in [[Quezon province|Quezon]] where she completed her elementary education from the King and Savior International School, and finished secondary education at the Quezon National High School under the scholarship grant from the [[Department of Science and Technology (Philippines)|Department of Science and Technology]]. She obtained her [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in Tourism, Hotel and Travel Industry Management from the [[Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila]].[http://cerphin.net/balita/Pamantasans-pride/artikulo/40190/ Pamantasan's pride]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. She was the Grand Winner in the 2009 International Beauty & Model Festival in China.[http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=464685&publicationSubCategoryId=70 RP bet wins in 2009 International Beauty & Model Festival in China]. In 2013, she was hired to become an ambassador for [[Solaire Resort & Casino]]. == Beauty titles == Jordan has modeled for designers including Renee Salud, and Nicky Martinez.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} She is a titleholder of both local and international beauty pageants. Her beauty titles include Miss Manila, Sanita Ti Ilocos Sur, 2nd Runner-Up in [[Mutya ng Pilipinas 2006]], and International Beauty & Model Festival 2009 grand winner.{{cite web|url=http://goodnewspilipinas.com/2009/05/07/april-love-wins-intl-beauty-pageant-in-china/ |title=April Love wins Int'l beauty pageant in China |publisher=Good News Pilipinas |date= |accessdate=2012-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722150002/http://goodnewspilipinas.com/2009/05/07/april-love-wins-intl-beauty-pageant-in-china/ |archivedate=2012-07-22 }}[http://adventuresofabeautyqueen.com/2009/05/04/bb-pilipinas-semi-finalist-april-love-jordan-wins-the-2009-international-beauty-model-festiva/ April Love wins the 2009 International Beauty Model Festival]. She became a finalist in [[Miss Philippines Earth 2006]], representing [[CALABARZON]] and in [[Binibining Pilipinas 2009]], representing [[Ilocos Sur]]. As the country's representative in Miss Tourism Queen of the Year International contest in Malaysia, she was awarded as Miss Secret Charm.[http://cerphin.net/balita/Pamantasans-pride/artikulo/40190/ Pamantasan's pride]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.[http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=464685&publicationSubCategoryId=70 RP bet wins in 2009 International Beauty & Model Festival in China]. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jordan, April Love}} [[Category:1988 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Santa Cruz, Manila]] [[Category:Filipino female models]] [[Category:Miss World Philippines winners]] [[Category:Binibining Pilipinas contestants]] [[Category:Mutya ng Pilipinas winners]] [[Category:Ilocano people]] [[Category:University of the City of Manila alumni]]

He is known for his contributions in [[econometrics]], including an early popular textbook.{{cite book |last=Blaug |first=Mark |last2=Sturges |first2=Paul |chapter=Christ, Carl Finley |title=Who's Who in Economics |location=Cambridge |publisher=MIT Press |year=1982 |isbn=0-262-02188-9 |pages=68–69 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=cuC5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA68 }} A native of [[Chicago]], Christ graduated with a BS in physics from the [[University of Chicago]] in 1943. He worked as junior physicist for the [[Manhattan Project]] from 1943 to 1945, and then as an Instructor in Physics at [[Princeton University]], 1945–46, before starting graduate studies in economics at the [[University of Chicago]].{{cite web |title=Curriculum Vitae: Carl F. Christ |work=JHU website |date= |url=http://krieger2.jhu.edu/economics/wp-content/uploads/cvs/christ_cv.pdf }} In 1970 he was elected as a [[Fellow of the American Statistical Association]].[http://www.amstat.org/awards/fellowslist.cfm View/Search Fellows of the ASA], accessed 2016-08-20. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://econ.jhu.edu/directory/carl-f-christ/ Website at Johns Hopkins University] * [http://hub.jhu.edu/2017/04/24/economist-carl-christ-dies/ Obituary ] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Christ, Carl Finley}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:American economists]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University faculty]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:Fellows of the Econometric Society]] {{US-economist-stub}}

{{Chinese|size=260|s={{linktext|零|八|宪|章}}|t={{linktext|零|八|憲|章}}|p=Língbā Xiànzhāng|w=|j=ling4 baat3 hin3 zoeng1|y=|showflag=|order=st}}'''Charter 08''' is a [[manifesto]] initially signed by 303 [[Chinese dissident]] [[intellectual]]s and [[human rights]] activists.{{cite news|url=http://news.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2008/12/200812171239.shtml|title=Over 5000 people have signed the Charter 08 (《零八宪章》签名已超过5000人)|date=17 December 2008|publisher=Boxun|accessdate=15 December 2008}} It was published on 10 December 2008, the 60th anniversary of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], adopting name and style from the anti-Soviet [[Charter 77]] issued by [[dissident]]s in [[History of Czechoslovakia (1948–1989)|Czechoslovakia]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/3690568/Chinese-dissidents-emulate-anti-Soviet-heroes-with-Charter-08.html|title=Chinese dissidents emulate anti-Soviet heroes with Charter 08 |last= Spencer|first=Richard |date=9 December 2008|publisher=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=10 December 2008}} Since its release, more than 10,000 people inside and outside China have signed the charter.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/21/opinion/21iht-edhavel.html?_r=1 A Nobel Prize for a Chinese Dissident], The New York Times, September 20, 2010[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/29/AR2009012903758.html Why China's leadership should talk to the Charter 08 movement], ''Washington Post'', 30 January 2009.[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2009/0131/1232923379427.html Small green shoots of rebellion among ordinary Chinese], ''[[Irish Times]]'', 31 January 2009. In 2009, one of the authors of Charter '08, [[Liu Xiaobo]], was sentenced to eleven years' imprisonment for "inciting subversion of state power" because of his involvement. A year later, Liu was awarded the [[2010 Nobel Peace Prize]] by [[Norway Nobel Committee]]. Seven years later in July 2017, he died of terminal liver cancer in the prison after having been granted medical parole. ==Demands== Many of the original signatories were prominent Chinese citizens inside and outside the government, including lawyers; a [[Tibet]]an poet and essayist, [[Woeser]]; and [[Bao Tong]], a former senior [[Communist Party of China|Communist Party]] official, who all faced a risk of arrest and jail. The Charter calls for 19 changes including an independent legal system, freedom of association and the elimination of [[One-party state|one-party rule]]. "All kinds of social conflicts have constantly accumulated and feelings of discontent have risen consistently," it reads. "The current system has become backward to the point that change cannot be avoided." China remains the only large world power to still retain an [[authoritarian]] system that so infringes on human rights, it states. "This situation must change! Political democratic reforms cannot be delayed any longer!"{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5313746.ece|title=Leading Chinese dissident, Liu Xiaobo, arrested over freedom charter |last= Macartney|first=Jane |date=10 December 2008|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=10 December 2008 |location=London}} Specific demands are: #Amending the [[Constitution of the People's Republic of China|Constitution]]. #[[Separation of powers]]. #Legislative democracy. #An [[Judicial independence|independent judiciary]]. #Public control of public servants. #Guarantee of [[human rights]]. #Election of [[civil servant|public officials]]. #Abolition of the [[hukou system]]. #[[Freedom of association]]. #[[Freedom of assembly]]. #[[Freedom of expression]]. #[[Freedom of religion]]. #[[Civic education]]. #[[Free market]]s and protection of [[private property]], including privatizing state enterprises and land. #Financial and [[tax reform]]. #[[Social security]]. #[[Environmental protection|Protection of the environment]]. #[[Federalism in China|A federated republic]]. #[[Truth and reconciliation commission|Truth in reconciliation]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/22210|title=Charter 08 Translated from Chinese by Perry Link The following text of Charter 08, signed by hundreds of Chinese intellectuals and translated and introduced by Perry Link, Professor of Chinese Literature at the University of California, Riverside|last=Link|first=Perry|publisher=The New York Review of Books|accessdate=10 December 2008}} The opening paragraph of the charter states:
{{cquote|This year is the [[Qinding Xianfa Dagang|100th year of China's Constitution]], the 60th anniversary of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], the 30th anniversary of the birth of the [[Democracy Wall]], and the 10th year since China signed the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]]. After experiencing a prolonged period of human rights disasters and a tortuous struggle and resistance, the awakening Chinese citizens are increasingly and more clearly recognizing that freedom, equality, and human rights are universal common values shared by all humankind, and that democracy, a republic, and constitutionalism constitute the basic structural framework of modern governance. A "modernization" bereft of these universal values and this basic political framework is a disastrous process that deprives humans of their rights, corrodes human nature, and destroys human dignity. Where will China head in the 21st century? Continue a "modernization" under this kind of authoritarian rule? Or recognize universal values, assimilate into the mainstream civilization, and build a democratic political system? This is a major decision that cannot be avoided.{{cite news|url=http://www.hrichina.org/public/contents/85717|title=Charter 08 (translated from the Chinese by Human Rights in China)|publisher=Human Rights in China|accessdate=10 December 2008|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120530173604/http://www.hrichina.org/public/contents/85717#|archive-date=2012-05-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}}}
==Response== ===China=== [[Image:Political Charter 08 Parade A02.jpg|thumb|right|Protest in Hong Kong against the arrest of Liu Xiaobo]] The [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese government]] has said little publicly about the Charter.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7819355.stm China aims to silence reform call], ''BBC News'', 12 January 2009. On 8 December 2008, two days before the 60th anniversary of the [[United Nations General Assembly]]'s adoption of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], [[Liu Xiaobo]] was detained by police, hours before the online release of the Charter.Human Rights in China, "[https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090429212836/http://www.hrichina.org/public/contents/85186 Independent Scholars Detained: Start of 2009 Crackdown?]," 9 December 2008. He was detained and later arrested on 23 June 2009, on charges of "suspicion of inciting the subversion of state power."[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/01/world/asia/01beijing.html A Manifesto on Freedom Sets China’s Persecution Machinery in Motion], ''New York Times'', 3 May 2009."[http://cn.chinareviewnews.com/doc/1010/0/3/6/101003632.html?coluid=0&kindid=0&docid=101003632 刘晓波因涉嫌煽动颠覆国家政权罪被依法逮捕]" (Liu Xiaobo Formally Arrested on 'Suspicion of Inciting Subversion of State Power' Charges), China Review News, 24 June 2009. Several [[List of Nobel Laureates|Nobel Laureates]] have written a letter to President [[Hu Jintao]] asking for his release; in response, the Chinese government has suppressed them:"[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ccb39784-d937-11dd-ab5f-000077b07658.html Beijing acts to stifle dissident call for reform]," ''[[Financial Times]]'', 3 January 2009. at least 70 of its 303 original signatories have been summoned or interrogated by police while domestic media have been forbidden to interview anyone who has signed the document. Police have also searched for or questioned a journalist, [[Li Datong]], and two lawyers, though none have been arrested. [[Media of the People's Republic of China|State media]] has been banned from reporting on the manifesto."[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/496234bac.html Media Ban on Charter Activists]," [[UNHCR]] and [[Radio Free Asia|RFA]], 24 December 2008. A [[Blog|blogging website]] popular with activists, [[bullog.cn]], which may have had ties to the Charter, has been shut down."[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Edgy-China-blog-site-shut-apf-14014893.html Edgy China blog site shut amid Internet porn sweep] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123044354/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Edgy-China-blog-site-shut-apf-14014893.html |date=January 23, 2009 }}," Associated Press, 9 January 2009. On 25 December 2009 Liu Xiaobo was sentenced to 11 years in prison for "inciting subversion of state power" activities by the court. On 8 October 2010 he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize "for his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China". ===Outside of China=== A number of governments, including those of the [[United States]]{{cite news|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2008/dec/113124.htm |title=Harassment of Chinese Signatories to Charter 08 Press Statement Sean McCormack, Spokesman Washington, DC |last=Sean McCormack |first=Sean McCormack |date=11 December 2008 |publisher=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=10 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214174715/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2008/dec/113124.htm |archivedate=December 14, 2008 }} and [[Germany]],{{cite news|url=http://news.trend.az/index.shtml?show=news&newsid=1367679&lang=EN|title=China retaliates against signatories of rights charter|date=11 December 2008|publisher=Trend News|accessdate=10 December 2008}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} as well as the opposition in [[Taiwan]],[http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/etn/news_content.php?id=821566&lang=eng_news&cate_img=46.jpg&cate_rss=news_Editorial Taiwan should heed "Charter 08" message], Taiwan News, 25 December 2008. have condemned the harassment of supporters of Charter 08 as well as hailing the Charter. Western press has generally covered the Charter positively, and international [[NGO]]s have supported its message."[https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090429212836/http://www.hrichina.org/public/contents/85186 Independent Scholars Detained: Start of 2009 Crackdown?]" Human Rights in China, 9 December 2008.{{cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2008/12/10/china-retaliation-signatories-rights-charter|title=China: Retaliation for Signatories of Rights Charter Critic Liu Xiaobo Remains in Police Custody|date=10 December 2008|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=10 December 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://www.internationalpen.org.uk/go/news/international-pen-protests-the-detention-of-leading-chinese-dissident-writer-liu-xiaobo|title=International PEN protests the detention of leading Chinese dissident writer Liu Xiaobo|date=17 December 2008|publisher=International Pen|accessdate=18 December 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126061440/http://www.internationalpen.org.uk/go/news/international-pen-protests-the-detention-of-leading-chinese-dissident-writer-liu-xiaobo|archivedate=26 January 2009|df=}} Other international figures, including the [[Dalai Lama]], have also voiced their support and admiration of the Charter.{{cite news|url=http://www.dalailama.com/news.326.htm |title=Statement From His Holiness the Dalai Lama |date=11 December 2008 |publisher=the 14th Dalai Lama |accessdate=11 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212221703/http://www.dalailama.com/news.326.htm |archivedate=December 12, 2008 }} There were also protests in Hong Kong demanding the release of Liu Xiaobo and other signatories. ==Signatories (selection)== {{Empty section|date=June 2018}} ==See also== {{Commons category}} *[[Charter 77]] (Czechoslovakia) *[[Charter 97]] (Belarus) *[[Human rights in the People's Republic of China]] *[[Law of the People's Republic of China]] *[[Fifth Modernization]] ([[Wei Jingsheng]]) {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *Full text of Charter 08: [http://www.2008xianzhang.info/chinese.htm Original Chinese] or [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072405/http://charter08.com/chinese/Charter%2008book.pdf Original Chinese (pdf)], [https://web.archive.org/web/20101214103401/http://www.charter08.com/charter08.php English translation by Perry Link],[http://www.chinafile.com/chinas-charter-08 English translation with postscript by Perry Link], [http://www.hrichina.org/en/content/238 English translation by Human Rights in China] *[http://www.2008xianzhang.info Charter 08 main site] (Chinese) -- includes updated news and signature lists *[https://archive.is/20130119092014/http://www.charter08.com/ Charter 08 main site] (English) -- includes updated news and ability to sign the charter online *"[http://chinadigitaltimes.net/china/charter-08/ News about Charter 08]," [[China Digital Times]] *"[http://hnn.us/blogs/entries/58055.html Chinese Support Charter 08]," [[History News Network]] {{Infobox person |name = Eileen Rose Busby |image = |caption = |birth_name = Eileen May Rose |birth_date = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1922|8|15}} |birth_place = [[Two Harbors, Minnesota]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|4|6|1922|8|15}} |death_place = [[San Diego, California]], U.S. |occupation = Antiques expert, author, writer |spouse = Richard Busby
James M. Scott |parents = [[Esther Rose]]
Frank Rose |party= |religion = |website = }} '''Eileen Rose Busby''' (August 15, 1922 – April 6, 2005) was an American [[author]] and [[antiques]] expert who was featured on [[HGTV]]'s ''Appraise It!'' show. ==Early life== {{citation needed span|text=Busby was born Eileen May Rose in [[Two Harbors, Minnesota]]. Her parents, Frank and [[Esther Rose]], relocated to [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] while she was still a baby. Busby taught herself to read when she was 3 years old, skipped a grade in school, and graduated from [[San Diego High School]] at age 16.|date=April 2015}} ==Biography== Busby, who first married [[James (Jim) Scott]] and then Richard Busby, often spoke before groups about antiques collecting. She also taught a how-to course for many years at [[Cuyamaca College]] and [[Grossmont College]], community colleges in [[El Cajon, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cuyamaca.edu/preview/pdf/2004%20Fall%20Preview.pdf|title=Grossmont College, On the Antiques Trail class schedule, Fall 2004|author=|date=|publisher=}} She wrote two books about the history and collecting of ''Royal Winton Porcelain'' and ''Cottage Ware''. Her third book, ''[[Chintz]] and Pastel Ware'', co-authored with daughter [[Cordelia Mendoza]], also an antiques expert and an appraiser,{{cite web|url=http://www.ana-appraisers.org/directory-of-appraisers.html|title=Directory of ANA Qualified Appraisers|author=|date=|website=Appraisers National Association}} is scheduled for posthumous publication by [[Schiffer Publishing]] in 2011. She was scheduled to lecture at the annual Chintz Convention, held in Northern California in April 2005, a month after her death.[http://www.collectx.com/news/collectorMag.cfm?domain_id=4&file_id=136&mode=remoteServe "Epitaph," ''Collector'' magazine, June 2005 (scroll to page 8)] Busby's book ''Cottage Ware'' is referenced in collector [[Judith Miller (antiques expert)|Judith Miller]]'s book ''Buy, Sell, or Keep'',{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s?url=search-alias=stripbooks&field-keywords=eileen+rose+busby&rh=n:283155,k:eileen+rose+busby&ajr=0|title=Amazon.com: eileen rose busby: Books|author=|date=|website=www.amazon.com}} and she is listed in ''[[Ralph Kovel|Kovels' Yellow Pages]]''.[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0609804170 Listing, ''Kovels' Yellow Pages''] Busby and her husband, Richard, lived in England for 10 years, some of it spent in a thatched roof cottage, from where they traveled the countryside researching [[Royal Winton]] and chintz. Busby wrote articles about their travels while Richard took photos, which were published in ''Sea'' magazine and ''International Yachtsman''. While living in England, Busby passed the UK's [[Mensa International|Mensa]] exam and became a member.{{cite news |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20050409/news_1m9busby.html |title=Eileen Rose Busby; writer, world traveler and antiques expert |author=Elizabeth Fitzsimons |work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |date=2005-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021134812/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20050409/news_1m9busby.html |archivedate=2007-10-21 |df= }} She also taught word processing at a U.S. military base. Busby was a member of the San Diego chapter of [[Mensa International|Mensa]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiego.us.mensa.org|title=Home - San Diego Mensa|author=|date=|website=www.sandiego.us.mensa.org}} and the San Diego Press Club,{{cite web|url=http://www.sdpressclub.org|title=Home - San Diego Press Club|author=|date=|website=San Diego Press Club}} and was featured in 2004 in the ''Antiques Road Show'''s newsletter. In 1999, Busby was featured as a collector on HGTV's ''Appraise It!'' show, taped at [[Butterfield & Butterfield]]'s auction house in Los Angeles.{{cite web|url=http://www.hgtv.com/hgtv/shows_ait|title=Home & Garden Television|author=|date=|publisher=}} She earned a bachelor's degree in sociology at age 62 from [[State University of New York]]. Also, she was a member of the San Diego Press Club.{{cite web|url=http://www.sdpressclub.com/|title=The San Diego Press Club|author=|date=|publisher=}} Upon her return to the US from England in 1990, she wrote articles for ''The Collector'', ''Antiques and Collectibles'', and ''West Coast Peddler.'' She also sold Royal Winton and chintz china pieces, which she had purchased in England, as a dealer at daughter Cordelia Mendoza's antiques store in [[Ocean Beach, San Diego, California|Ocean Beach]].{{cite web|url=http://antiquecottage.blogspot.com/|title=Cordelia's Cottage|author=|date=|website=antiquecottage.blogspot.com}} California. She and Jim Scott had five children, two of whom—[[J. Michael Scott]] and [[Cathy Scott]]—are also authors. Busby was also the sister of author and Orthodox Christian Hieromonk Father [[Seraphim Rose]] and the sister-in-law of former CIA Director [[Stansfield Turner]]. ==Books== * ''Royal Winton Porcelain: Ceramics Fit for a King'' 1998 * ''Cottage Ware: Ceramic Tableware Shaped As Buildings, 1920s-1990s'' 2003 * ''Computer Typing'' * ''Quick-Quick Type: Ten Easy Lessons : A Short, Simple Beginner or Refresher Course With Handy Reference Section'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://eileenrosebusby.blogspot.com/ Eileen Rose Busby official site] *[https://www.amazon.com/-/e/B001H9XF46 Amazon's Author Page] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071021134812/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20050409/news_1m9busby.html ''San Diego Union-Tribune'' obituary] *[http://www.collectx.com/news/collectorMag.cfm?domain_id=4&file_id=136&mode=remoteServe ''The Collector'' obituary] *[https://www.amazon.com/dp/1400048893 Listed in ''Official Guide to Flea Market Prices, 2nd ed''] *[http://www.sdpressclub.com/foghorn/0805/0805bus.htm "Remembering Eileen Busby," San Diego Press Club's ''Foghorn''] *[http://www.schifferbooks.com/newschiffer/book_template.php?isbn=0764317458 Publisher's book page for ''Cottage Ware''] *{{Find a Grave|72482332}} *{{IMDb name|5334609}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Busby, Eileen Rose}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:People from Two Harbors, Minnesota]] [[Category:Antiques experts]] [[Category:Collectors]] [[Category:American antiquarians]] [[Category:Writers from San Diego]] [[Category:20th-century American historians]] [[Category:Mensans]] [[Category:American women historians]] [[Category:20th-century American women writers]] [[Category:Writers from Minnesota]]

[[File:Arms of Michał Giedroyć.jpg|thumb|]] '''Giedroyć''' ([[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]]: Giedraitis; [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]]: Гедройц; [[French language|French]]: Guedroitz) is a Polish surname, originating from the [[Giedroyć family|Giedroyć princely family]] of the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]].
==Overview== The Second and Third Editions of the Lithuanian Chronicle relate that Giedrius ([[Palemonids]]), a brother of Grand Duke Traidenis of Lithuania (late 13th century), built a castle, named it [[Giedraičiai]], and adopted the title Prince of Giedraičiai.
A document issued by Grand Duke [[Vytautas|Vytautas of Lithuania]] in the period 1399–1429 settled a dispute between the Bishop of Vilnius and the Princes of Giedraičiai. Numerous members of the family were recorded in the 15th and 16th centuries, and thereafter, with the title Prince.
The two lines of the family for which coherent genealogies are available (the family's "central core") descend from (i) Prince Aleksander (late 15th century) and (ii) Prince Bartłomiej (died in 1524).<ref>For a full genealogy of those two lines see [http://www.angelfire.com/realm/gotha/gotha/gotha.htm On-line Gotha]</ref>
The 1569 Act of Union inaugurating the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth|Polish-Lithuanian Royal Commonwealth]] confirmed that, as previously in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, Lithuanian families of dynastic origin remained entitled to use the title Prince. Many subsequent Giedroyć family members, both of the Line of Aleksander and of the Line of Bartłomiej, were recorded with the title Prince – including several (of both Lines) whose right to the title was individually confirmed under Imperial Russian legislation of 1832. Other members did not seek such specific confirmation under the Russian Empire, but relied on confirmation of their noble status and princely origins under Russian legislation of 1801/3. The Imperial Russian heraldic authority classified these as "of the Princes".
Under the usage of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, as confirmed by the 1569 Act of Union, princely origins in themselves establish princely status.
==Armorial bearings== The Second Edition of the Lithuanian Chronicle records that a centaur was the armorial charge of the forebears of Giedrus. A decree issued in 1401 by Władisław Jagiello, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania, confirms the right of Prince Michał Giedroyć vel. Ratybor (baptized c.1387) to the arms Hippocentaurus "as used by his illustrious grandfather" Ginwill (2nd Duke of Giedrojcie and candidate to the grand ducal office of Lithuania).
But the earliest surviving illustrated Giedroyć armorial charge is a rose, on seals attached to state documents of 1431-4.
Through the 17th and 18th centuries, the centaur was used predominantly by most members of the family, sometimes in combination with the rose; while the descendants of Mikołaj (died 1657, sixth generation in the Line of Bartłomiej) continued to use the rose alone. But the centaur (sometimes with the rose, sometimes without) predominates in all the 19th century Russian records, even for the descendants of Mikołaj.
At the English College of Arms, the arms of [[Michal Giedroyc]] (born 1929, 16th generation in the Line of Bartłomiej) include both the rose and the centaur (called a sagittary in English heraldry) blazoned as follows: Per fess Or and Gules in chief a Rose Gules barbed and seeded proper and in base a Sagittary trippant to the dexter the head facing to the sinister his tail a serpent facing to the dexter holding in the hands a Bow with arrow drawn and set towards the head of the serpent all Or.
<gallery widths=150> File:Giedroyc Arms Wilno 1800.jpg|These arms appear on a document recording confirmation in 1800, by the Wilno General Assembly of Deputies for Pedigrees, of the princely descent of several members of the Giedroyć family (descendants of Benedykt Stanisław, five times great-grandson of the eponymous Aleksander in the Line of Aleksander)
File:Giedroyc Arms in Korwie Tree.jpg|These arms appear on the genealogy known as the “Korwie Tree”, which was commissioned before 1862 by descendants of Antoni Stanisław, seven times great-grandson of the eponymous Aleksander in the Line of Aleksander
File:Giedroyc Arms in Russia 1880.jpg|In 1880, Russian Czar Alexander II confirmed the right of Kazimir Michaił (eleventh generation in the Line of Bartłomiej) to bear these arms
File:Arms of Michał Giedroyć.jpg|Giedroyć arms recorded at the English College of Arms </gallery>
==Notable people==
Early bearers of the Giedroyć name included:
* Blessed [[:pl:Michał Giedroyć|Michał Giedroyć]], pre-dating the lines of Aleksander and Bartłomiej: buried in the church of St Mark in [[Kraków]], where he lived most of his life as a hermit renowned for gifts of prophecy and miracles; died in 1485. * son of the eponymous Bartłomiej in the Line of Bartłomiej: Mateusz Giedroyć (envoy to [[Ivan the Terrible]] 1551, Grand Ducal Governor of [[Vilnius]], Grand Ducal Marshal, died 1562/3). * grandsons of the eponymous Bartłomiej in the Line of Bartłomiej: Kacper-Dowmont Giedroyć (born c1535, signatory of the Act of Union 1569), [[Melchior Giedroyć]] (c1536-1609, Bishop of [[Samogitia]] and champion of the [[Lithuanian language]] and culture) and Martin-Dowmont Giedroyć (died 1621, Palatine of Mstislaw).
Other distinguished members of the two main lines of the family included:
* General [[:fr:Romuald Gedroitze|Romuald Tadeusz Giedroyć]] (1750–1824, 10th generation in the Line of Aleksander): fought as Major General in the 1792 war against Russia; played a major role in the 1794 uprising in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania; moved to Paris after the 1795 collapse and partition of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth; served as a General in [[Napoleon]]'s [[Grande Armée]] 1813; exiled in Archangel; then a Lieutenant General in the [[Congress Poland|Kingdom of Poland]] from 1815. * General Romuald's brother, Monsignor Piotr Kacper Giedroyć (died 1797): Secretary of State of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania 1790-95. * General Romuald's son, Józef Stefan Franciszek Ksawery Giedroyć (1787–1855): Colonel in the Grande Armée 1808-1815, promoted Brigadier General on the field of the [[Battle of Waterloo]]. * General Romuald's daughter, Kunegunda Franciszka Róża Giedroyć (1793–1883): Lady in Waiting to French Empress Josephine ([[Joséphine de Beauharnais]]), and to Russian Tsarina [[Elizabeth Alexeievna (Louise of Baden)]], wife of [[Alexander I of Russia]]. * [[:pl:Jan Stefan Giedroyć|Stefan Jan Giedroyć]] (1730–1803, 9th generation of the Line of Aleksander, a fifth cousin of General Romuald's father): Bishop of [[Livonia]], and later of Samogitia; a member of the Permanent Council of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. * [[:lt:Juozapas Arnulfas Giedraitis|Józef Arnolf Giedroyć]] (1754–1838, 9th generation in the line of Bartłomiej): Bishop of Samogitia from 1801, succeeding Bishop Stefan Jan above; benefactor of the Church, champion of education and patron of [[Lithuanian literature]], he published in 1816 the first translation of the [[New Testament]] into Samogitian (a dialect of the Lithuanian language). * [[:lt:Simonas Giedraitis|Szymon Tadeusz Michał Giedroyć]] (1764–1844, 10th generation in the line of Aleksander, first cousin once removed of Bishop Stefan Jan above): Bishop Coadjutor and - from 1829 - Administrator of Samogitia. * Ignacy Michał Giedroyć (1771–1829, 10th generation in the line of Aleksander, second cousin of Bishop of Szymon Tadeusz Michał above): Bishop Coadjutor of Samogitia, titular Bishop of Casio. * Ignacy Giedroyć (active 1763-1792, 9th generation of the line of Bartłomiej, first cousin of Bishop Józef Arnolf above): Quartermaster General of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania; Governor of Osiek; envoy in 1771 to [[Frederick the Great]] of [[Prussia]] and to [[Frederick II, Landgrave of Hesse-Kassel]] on behalf of the [[Bar Confederation]] (the Polish-Lithuanian anti-Russian movement). * Witold Giedroyć (1826/30-1885, 12th generation in the line of Aleksander) and his first cousin once removed Mikołaj Karol Giedroyć (1825–1894, 13th generation in the line of Aleksander): leaders of the anti-Russian conspiracy of 1863. * Franciszek Ignacy Dowmont Giedroyć (1869–1944, 14th generation in the line of Bartłomiej, third cousin five times removed of Bishop Józef Arnolf above): Professor of the History and Philosophy of Medicine at the [[University of Warsaw]], member of the [[Polish Academy of Sciences]], co-founder of the Polish school of the history of medicine. * [[Vera Gedroitz|Vera Ignatievna Giedroyc]] (Gedroitz) (1876–1932, 12th generation of the line of Bartłomiej, third cousin once removed of Bishop Józef Arnolf above, and sixth cousin twice removed of Franciszek Ignacy Dowmont above): the first female surgeon in Russia, her work on laparotomies during the Russo-Japanese War was among the first to achieve a high success rate, leading the Russian army to adopt the procedure and changing understandings of the correct treatment of abdominal wounds. She was surgeon to the imperial family at [[Tsarskoye Selo]] from 1909; worked at the front in World War I; and was professor (from 1923) and then chair of the surgery faculty (from 1930) at the Kiev Medical Institute. She also published poetry under the pseudonym Sergei Gedroitz. * Tadeusz Giedroyć (1889/90-1941, 15th generation in the line of Bartłomiej, third cousin once removed of Franciszek Ignacy Dowmont above): soldier, awarded the Polish Cross of Valour ([[Cross of Valour (Poland)]]) in 1918, and [[Cross of Independence]] in 1932; lawyer, administrator; Senator of the Second Polish Republic from 1938; imprisoned by the Russians in 1939, and subsequently murdered by the Soviet secret police, NKVD. * [[Jerzy Giedroyc]] (1906–2000, 14th generation in the line of Aleksander, fifth cousin twice removed of Witold above): founder, editor and publisher of the literary-political journal [[Kultura]]. The Polish parliament declared 2006 the year of Jerzy Giedroyć.
Current members of the family include:
* [[Coky Giedroyc]] (Mary-Rose Helen Giedroyć, born 1963, 17th generation in the line of Bartłomiej, granddaughter of Tadeusz above), film and TV director. * [[Mel Giedroyc]] (Melanie Clare Sophie Giedroyć born 1968, 17th generation in the line of Bartłomiej, granddaughter of Tadeusz above), English actress, presenter and writer.
Bearers of the name Guedroitz (the French version of the Russian version of Giedroyć) include:
* [[Wladimir Guedroitz]] (1869–1941, 13th generation in the line of Aleksander, great-great-nephew of Bishop Szymon Tadeusz Michał Giedroyć above): Chairman of the Commission for Control at the Russian Ministry of Finance. * [[Alexis Guedroitz]] (1923–1992, 15th generation in the line of Aleksander, grandson of Wladimir above), Belgian professor of Russian language, lecturer and writer. * [[Ania Guedroitz|Agnes Guedroitz]] (born 1949, 16th generation in the line of Aleksander, daughter of Alexis above), Belgian actress.
