{{use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = Mohammad Montazeri |image = Mohammad Montazeri.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = 1944 |birth_place = [[Najafabad]], [[Iran]] |death_date = 28 June 1981 (aged 37) |death_place = [[Tehran]], Iran |death_cause = [[Hafte Tir bombing|Bombing]] |resting_place =[[Fatima Masumeh Shrine]], [[Qom]] |residence = |nationality = [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] |alma_mater = |occupation = Cleric |years_active = 1960s–1981 |spouse = |children = |parents = [[Hossein Ali Montazeri]] (father)
Mah Sultan Rabbani (mother) |signature = |website = }} '''Abbas Mohammad Montazeri''' (1944 – 28 June 1981) was an Iranian cleric and military figure. He was one of the founding members and early chiefs of the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]]. He was killed in a 1981 bombing in Tehran. ==Early life== Born in [[Najafabad]]{{cite news|title=Lebanese paper on Hashemi|url=https://nsarchive.files.wordpress.com/2014/11/1986-11-03-fbis-ash-shiraa-on-mcfarlane.pdf|accessdate=16 May 2016|work=Al Shira|date=3 November 1986}} in 1944, Montazeri was the oldest son of [[Ayatollah|Grand Ayatollah]] [[Hossein Ali Montazeri]].{{cite web|author=Mehdi Khalaji|title=Supreme Succession. Who Will Lead Post-Khamenei Iran?|url=http://www.metransparent.com/IMG/pdf/mehdi_khalaji_supreme_succession.pdf|work=The Washington Institute|location=Washington DC|format=Policy Focus (No. 117)|date=February 2012|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416184302/http://www.metransparent.com/IMG/pdf/mehdi_khalaji_supreme_succession.pdf|archivedate=16 April 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite book|author=Steven O'Hern|title=Iran's Revolutionary Guard: The Threat that Grows While America Sleeps|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F9cJ1q-uFrcC&pg=PA216|accessdate=27 July 2013|date=31 October 2012|publisher=Potomac Books, Inc.|isbn=978-1-59797-701-2|page=216}}{{cite book|author1=Dominique Avon|author2=Anaïs-Trissa Khatchadourian|author3=Jane Marie Todd|title=Hezbollah: A History of the "Party of God"|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xOC6v4-XCHgC&pg=PA207 |accessdate=27 July 2013|date=10 September 2012|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-06752-3|page=207}} He had two brothers and two sisters.{{cite book|title=Montazeri, Hossein Ali (1922–)|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-2830800209.html|work=Biographical Encyclopedia of the Modern Middle East and North Africa|accessdate=15 October 2013|date=1 June 2008|publisher=Biographical Encyclopedia of the Modern Middle East and North Africa}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}} ==Career and activities== Montazeri was a low-ranking and radical cleric. He began opposition activities to [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|the Shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]], after the June 1963 events that led to the exile of [[Khomeini]].{{cite book|author1=Houchang Chehabi|author2=Rula Jurdi Abisaab|title=Distant Relations: Iran and Lebanon in the Last 500 Years|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=elHww0W0ZO4C&pg=PA182|accessdate=8 August 2013|date=2 April 2006|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-86064-561-7|page=182}} His father and he were both arrested by the Shah's security forces in March 1966.{{cite web|title=Biography of Hossein Ali Montazeri|url=http://www.amontazeri.com/english/Zendegi_e.htm|work=Montazeri website|date=October 2004|accessdate=27 July 2013}}{{cite web|title=Seyed Mohammad Khatami|url=http://www.iranchamber.com/history/mkhatami/mohammad_khatami.php|work=Iran Chamber Society|accessdate=27 July 2013}} In prison Mohammad was tortured and released in 1968. He left Iran for [[Pakistan]]. Then he settled in [[Najaf]], [[Iraq]], in 1971 and stayed there until 1975. Next he lived in [[Afghanistan]] and in other cities of Iraq. He headed an armed group that was based in [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]] and fought against Israeli forces.{{cite journal|author=Mohammad Ataie|title=Revolutionary Iran's 1979 endeavor in Lebanon|journal=Middle East Policy|date=Summer 2013|volume=XX|issue=2|pages=137–157|doi=10.1111/mepo.12026}} The group was founded by Montazeri and [[Ali Akbar Mohtashamipur]] with the aim of assisting liberation movements in Muslim countries.{{cite journal|author=Shahryar Sadr|title=How Hezbollah Founder Fell Foul of Iranian Regime|journal=IRN|date=8 July 2010|issue=43|url=http://iwpr.net/report-news/how-hezbollah-founder-fell-foul-iranian-regime|accessdate=28 July 2013}} Montazeri was trained in [[Fatah|Fatah camps]] in Lebanon.{{cite news|author=Robin Wright|title=Iran's Opposition Loses a Mentor but Gains a Martyr|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1949048,00.html|accessdate=27 July 2013|work=Time|date=21 December 2009}} In addition, he fought with [[Palestinian Liberation Organization|the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO)]] and other Palestinian and Shiite armed groups in the country. Montazeri was one of the three Iranian key officials along with [[Mostafa Chamran]] and Mohtashamipur who strengthened Iran's commitment to Lebanon.{{cite book|author=Ray Takeyh|title=Guardians of the Revolution:Iran and the World in the Age of the Ayatollahs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TAPs_r81AqQC&pg=PA70|accessdate=9 August 2013|date=28 April 2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-979313-6|page=70}} He was called Abu Ahmad by Lebanese people. Montazeri also travelled to Europe during this period. In 1978 he occupied [[Mehrabad Airport|the Mehrabad airport]] of [[Tehran]] with his 200 armed followers and demanded to go to [[Libya]] to search for [[Musa as-Sadr|Musa Al Sadr]], a Lebanese Shia cleric who disappeared in Libya in August 1978. He visited Ayatollah Khomeini when the latter was in exile in [[Paris]].{{cite book|author=Baqer Moin|title=Khomeini: Life of the Ayatollah|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b2OL9IEXaAgC&pg=PA194|accessdate=27 July 2013|year=1999|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-85043-128-2|page=194}} Before [[1979 Iranian Revolution|the 1979 Iranian revolution]] he was one of the people who promoted the idea of founding [[Islamic Revolutionary Guards|the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]].{{cite web|author=Afshon P. Ostovar|title=Guardians of the Islamic Revolution Ideology, Politics, and the Development of Military Power in Iran (1979–2009)|url=http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/64683/afshon_1.pdf;jsessionid=DF7BFA33BF18FF73E9117CB0504F14E1?sequence=1|publisher=University of Michigan|accessdate=26 July 2013|format=PhD Thesis|year=2009}} During the revolutionary process, he was called "Ayatollah Ringo" and "Red Sheikh".{{cite news|author=Gary G. Sick|title=Iran's Quest for Superpower Status|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/42020/gary-g-sick/irans-quest-for-superpower-status?page=show|accessdate=28 July 2013|work=Foreign Affairs|date=Spring 1987}} In order to export Islamic revolution to other countries he and [[Mehdi Hashemi]] founded one of the earliest groups, the Revolutionary Organization of the Masses of the Islamic Republic or Satja, in the spring of 1979.{{cite journal|author=Mohammad Ataie|title=Revolutionary Iran's 1979 Endeavor in Lebanon|journal=Middle East Policy|date=Summer 2013|volume=XX|issue=2|url=http://tonyrivera.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Revolutionary-Irans-1979-Endeavor-in-Lebanon.pdf|accessdate=18 May 2016}}{{cite book|title=Iran: A Country Study|year=1987|publisher=GPO for the Library of Congress|location=Washington|chapter-url=http://countrystudies.us/iran/100.htm|editor=Helen Chapin Metz|accessdate=28 July 2013|chapter=Concept of Export of Revolution}} In December 1979, he organized a campaign to support and join the Palestinian militants. fighting in [[Lebanese Civil War|the Lebanese civil war]].{{cite news|title=1,000 Iranians prepare to fight Israelis|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JJdjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f3oNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1104,3294139&dq=mohammad+montazeri&hl=en|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=The Phoenix|date=12 December 1979|agency=AP|location=Tehran}}{{cite book|author=Ehteshami Anoushiravan|title=After Khomeini: The Iranian Second Republic|year=1995|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|page=132|url=https://www.questia.com/read/103132654/after-khomeini-the-iranian-second-republic}} {{Subscription required|via=Questia}} His activities in the Satja caused conflicts with the government and he was forced to disband it. Then he and Hashemi joined the Guards. Montazeri headed a faction of the Guards in [[Tehran]] that functioned as a strong arm of [[Supreme Leader of Iran|the Supreme Leader]] Khomeini. It was called Freedom Movements Unit. In 1981 this faction was transformed into the office of liberation movements (OLM) which was firstly led by him and after his death, by Hashemi.{{cite journal|author=Toby Matthiesen|title=Hizbullah al-Hijaz: A History of The Most Radical Saudi Shi'a Opposition Group|journal=The Middle East Journal|date=Spring 2010|volume=64|issue=2|pages=179–197|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/mej/summary/v064/64.2.matthiesen.html|accessdate=19 August 2013|doi=10.3751/64.2.11}} An account with the name liberation movements was opened in the [[Bank Melli Iran|Melli Bank]] to get financial support from Iranians.{{cite book|author=Ali Alfoneh|title=Iran Unveiled: How the Revolutionary Guards Is Transforming Iran from Theocracy into Military Dictatorship|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z8N7ATqedvAC&pg=PA213|accessdate=16 May 2016|date=18 April 2013|publisher=AEI Press|isbn=978-0-8447-7255-4|page=213}} The OLM put into practice the Iranian support for the Shi‘a movements in Iraq and [[The Gulf States|the Gulf]] as well as those in [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Lebanon]] and [[Afghanistan]].{{cite book|author=Laurence Louër|title=Transnational Shia Politics: Religious and Political Networks in the Gulf|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B8wnEtH8oDgC&pg=PA179|accessdate=16 May 2016|date=January 2012|publisher=Hurst Publishers|isbn=978-1-84904-214-7|page=179}} At the founding and institutionalization phase of the Guards Montazeri became a member of the Revolutionary Guards Leadership Council in 1979 which was formed by [[Revolutionary Council of Islamic Revolution of Iran|the Revolutionary Council]] to oversee the future tasks of the Guard.{{cite web|author=Amir Farshad Ebrahim|title=IRGC History|url=http://iranbriefing.net/?p=201|work=Iran Briefing|accessdate=27 July 2013|date=7 September 2010}} He publicly declared in 1980 that the IRGC personnel "were awaiting deployment from Damascus."{{cite journal|author=Abbas William Samii|title=A Stable Structure on Shifting Sands: Assessing the Hizbullah-Iran-Syria Relationship|journal=Middle East Journal|date=Winter 2008|volume=62|issue=1|url=http://sino-west.org/sjtu/Stable.pdf|accessdate=12 August 2013}} Montazeri joined and led [[Muslim People's Republic Party|the Muslim People's Republic Party]]{{cite journal|author=Eric Rouleau|title=Khomenei's Iran|journal=Foreign Affairs|year=1980|volume=59|issue=1|url=http://ha6uq4xy8k.scholar.serialssolutions.com/?sid=google&auinit=E&aulast=Rouleau&atitle=Khomeini%27s+Iran&title=Foreign+affairs+(New+York,+N.Y.)&volume=59&date=1980&spage=1&issn=0015-7120|accessdate=5 August 2013}} and became a member of [[Majlis of Iran|the first Majlis]] in March 1980.{{cite book|author=Bahman Baktiari|title=Parliamentary Politics in Revolutionary Iran: The Institutionalization of Factional Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z_jPuuxfIv4C&pg=PA79|accessdate=27 July 2013|year=1996|publisher=University Press of Florida|isbn=978-0-8130-1461-6|page=79}} On the other hand, his party was disbanded after its members were either arrested or executed. In addition, Montazeri served at the supreme defense council{{cite news|title=Khomeini plans to oust cleric|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zHRkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dn4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1065,5160925&dq=mohammad+montazeri&hl=en|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=The Calgary Herald|date=18 May 1981|agency=Reuters|location=Tehran}} and was the prayer leader in Tehran until his death.{{cite news|title=64 leaders slain Iranian bombing|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YywdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SqUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5136,6712425&dq=mohammad+montazeri&hl=en|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=The Tuscaloosa News|date=29 June 1981|agency=AP|location=Beirut|page=2}} ===Views=== Montazeri was one of the most radical followers of Ayatollah Khomeini.{{cite news|author=Tony Badran|title=Moussa Sadr and the Islamic Revolution in Iran… and Lebanon|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/commentaryanalysis/moussa_sadr_and_the_islamic_revolution_in_iran_and_lebanon|accessdate=28 July 2013|work=Now Lebanon|date=8 September 2010}} Before the Iranian revolution he was close ally of [[Moammar Qaddafi]] and advocated strong ties with Libya. And, he did not support the approach of the Amal movement and Musa Al Sadr, because it was non-revolutionary. Montazeri was also a fierce critic of [[Interim Government of Iran (1979)|the interim government]] led by [[Mahdi Bazargan]] due to the same reason. Both Montazeri and his father actively encouraged the rebellion of [[Shia Muslim]]s against the governments in the Muslim countries and also, strongly argued for the export of the Islamic regime to other countries, often called "Islamic Internationale".{{cite book|author=Ali Alfoneh|title=Iran Unveiled: How the Revolutionary Guards Is Transforming Iran from Theocracy into Military Dictatorship|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z8N7ATqedvAC&pg=PA213|accessdate=27 July 2013|date=18 April 2013|publisher=AEI Press|isbn=978-0-8447-7255-4|page=213}} The latter goal was mostly achieved through the OLM, and it is one of two pillars of ideology guided the revolution along with the propagation of [[Islam]].{{cite journal|author=Shmuel Bar|title=Iranian terrorist policy and "export of revolution"|journal=Interdisciplinary Center|year=2009|url=http://www.herzliyaconference.org/_Uploads/2903Iranian.pdf|accessdate=28 July 2013}} In addition, he argued that all Muslims could enter Islamic states without passport or visas.{{cite journal|author=Shaul Bakhash|title=The Islamic Republic of Iran, 1979-1989|journal=The Wilson Quarterly|volume=13|issue=4|pages=54–62|jstor=40257945}} Montazeri also supported for the development of links with Shia Muslims in [[Lebanon]]. He tried to make Iran a key player in [[Palestinian-Israeli conflict|the Palestinian-Israeli conflict]]. Just three days before his death, he argued for the execution of the ousted prime minister [[Abolhassan Bani Sadr]]'s followers. ===Controversy=== At the initial phase of the Iranian revolution the activities of the Montazeri's group, Satja, led to tensions between Montazeri and both the Guards's leadership and the provisional government. His father, Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, publicly reprimanded him and stated that Mohammad had poor mental health because he had been tortured by the former Shah's secret police. Eventually, elder Montazeri disassociated himself from his son’s activities. Mohammad Montazeri was part of the Libya-friendly group in the court of Khomeini and there was a feud between his group and the faction, called "Syrian mafia", led by [[Sadegh Ghotbzadeh]].{{cite news|author=Mark Gayn|title=Into the depths of a boiling caldron|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DCNlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SogNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1340,5195980&dq=mohammad+montazeri&hl=en|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=Edmonton Journal|date=20 December 1979}} Ghotbzadeh's faction was called previously [[Liberation Movement of Iran|the Liberation Movement of Iran (LMI)]], and Mostafa Chamran was also part of it. In addition, Montazeri had serious disagreements with Ayatollah [[Mohammad Beheshti]], cofounder of the Islamic Republican Party. ==Death== Montazeri was killed in [[Hafte Tir bombing|a bombing]] at the central headquarters of the then ruling party, Islamic Republican Party, in Tehran on 28 June 1981. The Islamic Republic of Iran suspected various organizations and individuals, including [[SAVAK]], the Iraqi regime, the [[People's Mujahedin of Iran]], the United States, royalist army officers, and "internal mercenaries". It also executed 4 Iraqi agents and Mehdi Tafari for the incident.{{cite book|title=Mujahedin-E Khalq (MEK) Shackled by a Twisted History|author= Lincoln P. Bloomfield Jr. |year=2013|publisher=University of Baltimore College of Public Affairs|isbn=978-0615783840|pages=27}}{{Citation|title=33 HIGH IRANIAN OFFICIALS DIE IN BOMBIMG AT PARTY MEETING; CHIEF JUDGE IS AMONG VICTIMS|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/world/33-high-iranian-officials-die-bombimg-party-meeting-chief-judge-among-victims.html|newspaper=NY Times|date= 1981-06-29}}{{cite book |first=Ervand |last=Abrahamian |title=Radical Islam: The Iranian Mojahedin |publisher=I.B. Tauris|year=1989|isbn=978-1-85043-077-3|pages=219–220}}{{cite news|author=Meir Javedanfar|title=Filling Montazeri's shoes in Iran|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/dec/21/iran-ayatollah-montazeri-death|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=21 December 2009}}{{cite news|title=Iranians mass for funeral|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=19810630&id=A7o0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=AXUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3228,6104172|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=The Day|date=30 June 1981}} The death toll in the attack was 73, including Behesti, cabinet ministers and the members of the Majlis.{{cite web|author=Semira N. Nikou|title=Timeline of Iran's Political Events|url=http://iranprimer.usip.org/resource/timeline-irans-political-events|work=United States Institute of Peace|accessdate=27 July 2013}} A state funeral was held for the victims on 30 June and a week of mourning was proclaimed. Montazeri was buried in the [[Fatima Masumeh Shrine]] in Qom where his father would also be buried on 21 December 2009.{{cite web|title=Funeral of A Revered Ayatollah, Hossein Ali Montazeri|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/dec/1218.html|work=Payvand|accessdate=2 August 2013|date=21 December 2009}} ==Legacy== A street in [[Qom]] was named after him, Martyr Mohammad Montazeri boulevard.{{cite news|title=Million-Man Show of Force|url=http://www.roozonline.com/english/news3/newsitem/archive/2009/december/23/article/million-man-show-of-force.html|accessdate=27 July 2013|work=Rooz|date=23 December 2009}} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Montazeri, Mohammad}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:Iranian Shia Muslims]] [[Category:Iranian clerics]] [[Category:People of the Iranian Revolution]] [[Category:Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps officers]] [[Category:Muslim People's Republic Party politicians]] [[Category:Members of the 1st Islamic Consultative Assembly]] [[Category:People murdered in Iran]] [[Category:Assassinated Iranian politicians]] [[Category:Iranian revolutionaries]] [[Category:People from Najafabad]]

{{Infobox person | name = Morris Krok | image = Natural foodstuff 004.JPG | alt = | caption =Fruitarianism | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1931|04|28}} | birth_place = South Africa | death_date = {{Death date and age|2005|10|01|1931|04|28}} | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = [[Fruitarianism]] | notable_works = }}
'''Morris Krok''' (28 April 1931 – October 2005) was a [[South African]] [[author]],<ref>Blatant raw foodist propaganda!, Joe Alexander, Blue Dolphin Publishing, 1990, page 47 "Morris Krok, from South Africa, is another outstanding rawfoodist author, very much of a spiritual bent."</ref> [[publisher]] and [[health]] [[educator]].
== Biography ==
'''Background'''
Morris Krok was born in [[Johannesburg]]<ref>South African Jewry, Leon Feldberg, Fieldhill Pub. Co., 1976, page 240, "Morris Krok. Director of Company. Born Johannesburg, 28 April 1931, son of Simon and Sarah Krok."</ref> and brought up in [[Durban]],<ref>Survival Into The 21st Century: Planetary Healers Manual, Viktoras Kulvinskas, Omnagod Press, 1979 - 323 pages, “In 1961, Dr. Morris Krok of Durban South Africa, published “Conquest of Disease,” where he reproduced a part of a speech by Dr. Moore, which was written up in: “Life Natural, Ganeshganar, Padukottai, S. Ry, India. Nov. 1960″.</ref> [[South Africa]]. As a young man, he started to seek solutions for his health problems and was influenced by [[Naturopathy|natural healing]] writers of the 20th century such as [[Vincent Priessnitz]], [[Louis Kuhne]], [[Harry Benjamin]], [[Arnold Ehret]], [[Dugald Semple]],<ref>Dugald Semple, The Sunfood Way To Health, Health For All, 1956, 138 pages, "Your food determines in a large measure how long you shall live — how much you shall enjoy life, and how successful your life shall be."</ref> [[George R. Clements]], [[Walter Siegmeister]],<ref>Creation of the Superman, Raymond W. Bernard, Health Research, 1996, Preface (Morris Krok), "This book reads like a fascinating story."</ref> [[Essie Honiball]]<ref>The fruit hunters: a story of nature, adventure, commerce and obsession, Adam Gollner, Simon and Schuster, 2008, page 97, "Morris Krok's Fruit: The Food and Medicine of Man relates how he attended a fruitarian lecture with Essie Honiball, author of I Live On Fruit. Asked what one should eat, the answer is: "Fruit, of course."</ref> and [[Johnny Lovewisdom]]. He also studied [[new age]], [[occult]], [[esoteric]], [[yogic]], [[Spirituality|spiritual]] and [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] writings from the [[Eastern world|East]]. Krok migrated to [[California]] to develop his work and writings, dedicating his life to the quest for knowledge about health, [[vitality]] and [[higher consciousness]]. A regular [[marathon]] runner, Krok died from [[cancer]] of the leg in 2005,<ref>[http://www.vibranthealthandwealth.com/vibrance/articles/krok.html Who Was Morris Krok?, David Klein, Living Nutrition, Volume 20, 2007, "The man who had written Formula For Long Life and had a small cult-like global following had died of cancer at age 74."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717195159/http://www.vibranthealthandwealth.com/vibrance/articles/krok.html |date=2011-07-17 }}</ref> blaming "his problem on his terrible diet in his youth and on cooked food temptations from family".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Patenaude|first1=Frederic|title=Morris Krok Passed Away|url=http://fredraw.typepad.com/personal/2005/10/morris_krok_is_.html|website=Peaches and a Guitar|accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref>
'''Beliefs'''
In the 1950s, a popular South African [[newspaper]] featured a story about Krok’s belief that [[fruit]] was the ideal food for [[humankind]].<ref>Who Was Morris Krok? by David Klein Ph.D, Obituary, Living Nutrition, Volume 20, {{cite web |url=http://www.vibranthealthandwealth.com/vibrance/articles/krok.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717195159/http://www.vibranthealthandwealth.com/vibrance/articles/krok.html |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref> In the 1990s and 2000s, David Klein Ph.D., publisher of Living Nutrition, chronicled Krok's famous sayings including "Man will always get colds if he persists in eating large quantities of mucous forming foods in the form of [[starch]], [[dairy products]] and [[animal fat]]s." and "Health is the balance between assimilation and elimination.” in the magazine.<ref>[http://www.livingnutrition.com/fwn/read.php?1,426,429 ‘Life’s Most Transforming Teachings: Morris Krok’s Quest, Morris Krok's Teachings by David Klein Ph.D, Living Nutrition, 9 October 2005]</ref><ref>Who Was Morris Krok? by David Klein Ph.D, Obituary, Living Nutrition, Volume 20, http://www.livingnutrition.com/backissues/contents.html#20</ref> Central to Krok's thinking was that mucusless foods held the key to good health. In the article, ''A Yogic Perspective''<ref>''A Yogic Perspective: Light alkalizing foods - the key to endurance and good health'', Morris Krok, Living Nutrition, vol. 6, 1990s</ref> he describes how "To heal and avoid [[illness]], one must [[Alkaline|alkalinize]] the [[Human body|body]] through a [[diet (nutrition)|diet]] of predominately [[wikt:raw|raw]] fruits and [[vegetables]]."
'''Writings'''
Krok wrote books on [[Detoxification (alternative medicine)|detoxification]], internal purification, [[Sustainable living|natural living]], [[self-healing]], [[fruitarianism]], [[fasting]], [[rawfoodism|living foods]], raw [[nutrition]], [[physical culture]], [[hatha yoga]], [[meditation]], [[deep breathing]], higher consciousness, [[radiant energy]], [[life extension]] and [[vitalism]]. As well as being an author, Krok published several books by other authors including [[Johanna Brandt]],<ref>The Grape Cure, Joanna Brandt, Durban: Essence of Health Publishers</ref> Otto Abramowski<ref>Water Into Gold, Ernestine Hill, Angus and Robertson, 1965, 291 pages, "Dr. Otto Abramowski was the grandson of a Governor of Warsaw, and had been a surgeon in the Franco-Prussian War of 1870, of which he told many a stirring tale."</ref> and [[Theos Bernard]], through Essence of Health Publishers.
'''Golden Path'''
Krok's book ''Golden Path To Rejuvenation'' described how a [[non-toxic]] diet and the [[osmotic pressure]] of [[rainwater]] could detoxify and purify the [[Biological membrane|membrane]]s and [[Tissue (biology)|tissues]] of the body. Krok believed that internal purification, was the direct and most effective way for a longer and youthful life. He described how not everything humans eat is used by the body, showing how accumulated [[wastes]] and [[toxins]] caused by an unnatural diet and other substances, result in illness and premature [[ageing]].<ref>''Experiences in Euphoria'', USA: Living Nutrition, Vol. 7, 1990s "euphoria can only be experienced more often if mucous-forming and toxic foods are not eaten, so that the 24 feet of small intestines and few feet of colon, become scrupulously clean. When these are kept clean, this cleanliness will spill over to the lungs, sinuses, nasal passages and eustachian tubes. What I infer from these experiences is that the wonderful feeling of euphoria, does not depend on a specific vitamin, mineral, supplement or food, but on the thorough natural cleansing of the entire body. Foods that are the big culprits are all starches, dairy products, eating too much of any cooked food, as well as of natural concentrated raw foods such as avocado, nuts, dried fruits and dates."</ref> His internal purification programme was designed to help increase [[longevity]] and remain youthful.<ref>''Experiences in Euphoria'', USA: Living Nutrition, Vol. 7, 1990s, "If civilized man puts himself on an elimination program for an extended period of time, he will be shocked by the amount of stored slime that is dislodged and eliminated from the 30 feet of intestines and delicate bronchial tubes of the lungs. As he discovers the principle of detoxification, he will understand why no pill, special food or stretching exercise can clear the large thick, salty, toxic accumulations that foul the body..... The sticky, slimy and toxic substances contained in starchy foods, dairy products and animal foods will in a short time, neutralize hours of physical endeavor."</ref> He believed internal cleansing in conjunction with [[plant]] [[food]]s was the 'golden path'. The book also explained the ''[[yogic]] [[vomiting|vomit]]'' technique, a central part of the detoxification regime he endorsed.
'''Legacy'''
Krok was one of a series of 20th-century writers who wrote about fruitarianism, raw nutrition, fasting, detoxification, yoga<ref>Yoga World Wide, Meenakashi Devi Gitananda, Satya Press, 1972, page 52, "Yoga is expounded in various parts of Africa. Morris Krok and Swami Sahajananda are in South Africa."</ref> and higher consciousness. His contemporaries included Brian Clement Ph.D,<ref>Living foods for optimum health: staying healthy in an unhealthy world, Brian R. Clement, Theresa Foy DiGeronimo, Crown Publishing Group, 1998</ref> Dr. Douglas N. Graham,<ref>80/10/10 Diet: Balancing Your Health, Your Weight, and Your Life One Luscious Bite at a Time, Douglas N. Graham, FoodnSport Press, 2006 - 348 pages</ref> [[Viktoras Kulvinskas]] and Robert Gray.<ref>The colon health handbook: new health through colon rejuvenation, Robert Gray, San Francisco: Emerald Publishing, 2002, 74 pages</ref> Authors who have endorsed Krok's writings in their books include John McCabe,<ref>Sunfood Living: Resource Guide for Global Health, John McCabe, North Atlantic Books, 2007, 576 pages</ref> Joe Alexander,<ref>Blatant raw foodist propaganda!, or, Sell your stove to the junkman and feel great!, or, Consider your true nature, Joe Alexander, Blue Dolphin Publishing, 1990, page 47, "Morris Krok, from South Africa, is another outstanding rawfoodist author, very much of a spiritual bent.</ref> [[Gary Null]],<ref>Complete Handbook of Nutrition, Gary Null, Random House, 1973</ref> Benito De Donno<ref>Glimpses Of Reality, Benito De Donno, 2002, 424 pages</ref> and David Wolfe.<ref>The Sunfood Diet Success System: 36 Lessons in Health Transformation, David Wolfe, Maul Brothers, 2000, "Consider the words of Morris Krok in his book Diet, Health, And Living On Air: "In the metabolism of fats, sugars, and starches, the waste which is left behind is carbon dioxide and water."</ref>
==Criticisms==
Morris Krok advocated a fruitarian diet in his writings as the optimal diet and described how at stages during his life, he lived "only on fruits".<ref>Morris Krok, ''Fruit: The Food and Medicine For Man'', Connecticut: O'Mangod Press, (1961). page 17, Chapter 8: "It had taken me almost ten years of continual reading and meditation before I had the courage to live only on fruits.", Page 40, Chapter 19: "At the time of the incident I was living on all fruit.", Page 46, Chapter 21: "After living on fruit for about four months, raw vegetables tasted flat."</ref> It is claimed that he later advised against a diet of "only fruit"<ref>[http://www.beyondveg.com/billings-t/bio/billings-t-bio-1b.shtml Tom Billings: dietary bio--continued, Part B, section, Other Important Lessons, August 2000<!-- Bot generated title -->]"By the way, Morris Krok now advises against a diet of only fruit, and he is an open, honest, and very nice person."</ref> however, it was subsequently reported that Krok's diet consisted of "just fruit".<ref>Who Was Morris Krok?, David Klein Ph.D, Living Nutrition, Volume 20, 2007, {{cite web |url=http://www.vibranthealthandwealth.com/vibrance/articles/krok.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717195159/http://www.vibranthealthandwealth.com/vibrance/articles/krok.html |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }} "Someone who attended the talk reported he said that at the moment he was eating a diet of just fruit. I’d never heard that he ate exclusively fruit; however, it would not be surprising if he did so for varying periods of time."</ref>
==Writings==
Books and booklets written by Morris Krok, many published through Essence Of Health Publishers:
*Amazing New Health System: Inner Clean Way, 1978 *Amazing New Health System: Inner Clean Way, Essence of Health, Wandsbeck, South Africa, 2001, {{ISBN|0-620-27362-3}} *Cream of Yoga, 1987 (booklet) *Diary Of A Health & Truth Seeker, 1967, 1969 *Diet Health And Living On Air, 1973 *El Frugivorismo de Durban, Barcelona: Cuadernos De Naturismo, {{ISBN|84-300-2049-7}}, 1980 *Formula For Long Life, 1967, 1977 and 2001 (originally From The Deathbed To Boisterous Health) *From The Deathbed To Boisterous Health, 1962, 1963 *Fruit: The Food And Medicine For Man, 1961 (alternate title ''The Conquest Of Disease'') <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soilandhealth.org/RealBookList.aspx?collection=0203 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101223043309/http://soilandhealth.org/RealBookList.aspx?collection=0203 |archivedate=2010-12-23 |df= }}</ref> *Fruit: The Food And Medicine For Man, Connecticut: O'mangod, 1967 *Golden Path To Rejuvenation: Life’s Most Important Knowledge, 1964 *Hatha Yoga In Its Moods Multivarious, 1959 *Hatha Yoga: The Vibrant Science Of Life, 1975 *Health, Diet, and Living on Air (1964) *Health Truths Eternal, 1964 *Health Truths Eternal (booklet) *Metaphysical Diary, 1960s *Mystic Story (booklet) *The Greater Miracle of Life, 1964 *The Kindred Soul: Teachings Of Eternal Truth, 1968 *Pathway To Truth, 1974 *Raw Juice Therapy & Self-Help, 1967 *Science of Natural Healing (booklet), 1961 *Soul Knowledge, 1960s (formerly Revelations Of The New Age) *The Conquest Of Disease, 1961 *The Fog Lifts - autobiography (unpublished)

*Fast Way To Health - Frank Mccoy *Fruitarian Diet & Physical Rejuvenation - Otto Abramowski *Fruitarian System Of Healing - Otto Abramowski, 1976 *Fruitarianism: Compassionate Way To Transform Health - Hannah Hurnard *Garden Of The Lord - Hannah Hurnard *Gardening Without Digging - Albert Guest, 1973 *Hatha Yoga - Theos Bernard, 2001, {{ISBN|0-9584460-1-6}} *Heaven Lies Within Us - Theos Bernard, 2002, {{ISBN|0-9584461-1-3}} *I Live On Fruit - Essie Honiball, 2002 *My Healing Secret *The Physiological Enigma of Woman: The Mystery Of Menstruation - Raymond Bernard *Prenatal Origin Of Genius - Raymond W. Bernard, (Foreword and Edited by Morris Krok), 1962 *The Grape Cure - Joanna Brandt *Yoga Gave Me Superior Health (Heaven Lies Within Us) - Theos Bernard *Yoga System Of Health - Yogi Vithaldas

Hartley Hennessy *Heaven Lies Within Us - Theos Bernard *Mucusless Diet Healing System - Arnold Ehret *Nature The Healer - Vera Richter *New Science Of Healing - Louis Kuhn *A Plea for The Order of the Golden Age - H. J. Williams *Pacifying Panicking People - *Provoker - John Toby *Raw Eating - Aterhov T. '''Perri Peltz''' (born 11 March 1960) is an American broadcast journalist.
== Career ==
Peltz worked at [[WNBC]] from 1987 to 1996 where she co-anchored ''Weekend Today in New York'' with Ken Taylor, and weekend editions of ''News 4 New York'' at 6 and 11 with [[Ralph Penza]].
Peltz joined ''[[Dateline NBC]]'' for two years. During that period, she often anchored live news coverage on [[NBC]]'s [[24-hour news cycle|24-hour]] [[United States cable news|cable news]] television channel [[MSNBC]].
She then worked for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC's]] ''[[20/20 (US television show)|20/20]]'' for two years until she moved to [[CNN]] where she stayed until 2002.
Peltz left CNN to produce a feature film, ''[[Knights of the South Bronx]]'' starring [[Ted Danson]]. The film was based on the real-life story of a [[middle school]] [[chess team]] from the [[South Bronx]] that became national chess champions. The film aired on the [[A&E Network]].
Peltz then went to work for the [[Robin Hood Foundation]] in [[New York City]]. Robin Hood is a [[non-profit organization]] dedicated to fighting [[poverty]]. While at Robin Hood, Peltz wanted to tell the stories of the people who were working on the front lines in the war against poverty.
In 2005 she rejoined [[WNBC-TV|WNBC]] after a nine-year absence to co-anchor ''[[Live at Five (WNBC TV series)|Live at Five]]'' with [[Sue Simmons]]. She returned to WNBC to report on those people and the differences they were making. She also anchored ''Live at Five'' with Sue Simmons from 31 May 2005, until 12 March 2007, when she began hosting her own half-hour lifestyle broadcast titled ''News 4 You''. The program was part of WNBC's attempt to boost ratings and features stories from the consumer, health and entertainment worlds.
On 10 September 2007, WNBC cancelled ''News 4 You''. Peltz continued to report both for WNBC and for NBC Network on people who were making a difference.
Peltz co-produced and co-directed the documentary ''[[Prison Dogs]]'', which premiered at the 2016 [[Tribeca Film Festival]].
== Education == Peltz graduated from [[The Dalton School]] in New York City, and then went to [[Brown University]] and then to [[Columbia University|Columbia]] for a [[Masters in Public Health]]. In 2008, she left WNBC to attend [[medical school]].
==Charitable work== In 2015, Peltz, a practitioner of [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]], supported the work of the [[David Lynch Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Women in the Media Who Meditate|url=http://www.davidlynchfoundation.org/broadcast/|publisher=David Lynch Foundation|accessdate=17 May 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YayqombX?url=http://www.davidlynchfoundation.org/broadcast/|archivedate=17 May 2015|quote=Eight nationally renowned women leaders in the media who meditate gathered on April 16, 2015 in New York City to raise awareness about the benefits of the evidence-based Transcendental Meditation technique for overcoming stress, improving performance, and enhancing work-life balance in their lives.|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>

{{For|the band|Prunella Scales (band)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Prunella Scales | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|size=100%}} | image = Prunella Scales in 2010.JPG | caption = Scales pictured in 2010 | birth_name = Prunella Margaret Rumney Illingworth | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1932|06|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Sutton Abinger]], [[Surrey]], England | education = [[Moira House Girls School]], [[Eastbourne]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = Pru | occupation = Actress | years_active = 1952–2014 | spouse = {{marriage|[[Timothy West]]|1963}} | children = 2, [[Samuel West]] & Joseph West | family = 1 stepdaughter, Juliet }} '''Prunella Margaret Scales''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE}} (née '''Illingworth'''; born 22 June 1932), is an English actress best known for her role as [[Basil Fawlty]]'s wife [[Sybil Fawlty|Sybil]] in the BBC comedy ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'' and her [[BAFTA award]]-nominated role as [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] in ''[[A Question of Attribution]]'' (''[[Screen One]]'', BBC 1991) by [[Alan Bennett]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000123/1992 |title=1992 BAFTA Awards |work=IMDb |accessdate=21 July 2015}} ==Early life== Scales was born in [[Sutton Abinger]], [[Surrey]], the daughter of Catherine (née Scales), an actress, and John Richardson Illingworth, a cotton salesman.{{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/72/Prunella-Scales.html |title=Prunella Scales Biography (1932-) |work=filmreference.com |accessdate=21 July 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Image%3A+British+TV+stalwart+Best+%5B...%5D.-a0297856615 |title=Image: British TV stalwart Best [...]. |work=thefreelibrary.com |date=28 July 2012 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} She attended [[Moira House Girls School]], [[Eastbourne]].{{cite web |url=http://www.moirahouse.co.uk |title=Home |work=Moira House |accessdate=21 July 2015}} She has a younger brother, Tim ("Timmo"). Scales' parents moved their family to Bucks Mill near [[Bideford]] in [[Devon]] in 1939 at the start of the [[Second World War]]. Scales herself (and her brother) were evacuated to [[Near and Far Sawrey|Near Sawrey]] in [[Cumberland |Cumberland]] (as the county was known at that time). ==Career== Scales started her career in 1951 as an assistant stage manager at the [[Bristol Old Vic]]. Throughout her career, Scales has often been cast in comic roles. Her early work included the second UK adaptation of ''Pride and Prejudice'' (1952), ''[[Hobson's Choice (1954 film)|Hobson's Choice]]'' (1954), ''[[Room at the Top (1959 film)|Room at the Top]]'' (1959) and ''[[Waltz of the Toreadors (film)|Waltz of the Toreadors]]'' (1962). Her career break came with the early 1960s sitcom ''[[Marriage Lines]]'' starring opposite [[Richard Briers]]. In addition to ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'', she has had roles in [[BBC Radio 4]] [[Situation comedy|sitcoms]], and comedy series including ''[[After Henry (radio series)|After Henry]]'', ''[[Smelling of Roses]]'' and ''[[Ladies of Letters]]''; on television she starred in the [[London Weekend Television]]/[[Channel 4]] series ''[[Mapp and Lucia (Channel 4 TV series)|Mapp & Lucia]]'' based on the novels by [[E. F. Benson]]. She played [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] in [[Alan Bennett]]'s ''[[A Question of Attribution]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbcamerica.com/shows//blog/2012/06/happy-80th-birthday-prunella-scales|title=Happy 80th Birthday, Prunella Scales! - Anglophenia - BBC America|work=BBC America}} In 1973, Scales was cast with [[Ronnie Barker]] in ''One Man's Meat'' which formed part of Barker's ''[[Seven of One]]'' series, also for the BBC. Her later film appearances include ''[[Escape from the Dark]]'' (1976), ''[[The Hound of the Baskervilles (1978 film)|The Hound of the Baskervilles]]'' (1978), ''[[The Boys from Brazil (film)|The Boys From Brazil]]'' (1978), ''[[The Wicked Lady (1983 film)|The Wicked Lady]]'' (1983), ''[[The Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne]]'' (1987), ''[[Stiff Upper Lips]]'' (1997), ''[[Howards End]]'' (1992) and ''[[Wolf]]'' (1994). For the [[BBC Television Shakespeare]] production of ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'' (1982) she played Mistress Page and the ''[[Theatre Night]]'' series (BBC) she appeared with her husband Timothy West in the [[Joe Orton]] farce ''[[What the Butler Saw (play)|What the Butler Saw]]'' (1987) playing Mrs Prentice. For ten years, Prunella appeared with [[Jane Horrocks]] in advertisements for UK supermarket chain [[Tesco]]. In 1996, Scales starred in the television film, ''Lord of Misrule'', alongside [[Richard Wilson (Scottish actor)|Richard Wilson]], [[Emily Mortimer]] and [[Stephen Moyer]]. The film was directed by Guy Jenkins and filming took place in [[Fowey]] in [[Cornwall]]. In 1997, Scales starred in [[Chris Barfoot]]'s [[science-fiction]] film [[Short film|short]] ''Phoenix'' which was first aired in 1999 by [[NBC Universal]]'s [[Syfy|Sci Fi Channel]].{{cite web |url= http://www.spike.com/video-clips/kph5ki/phoenix |title=Phoenix |work=SPIKE |year=2015 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} Scales played 'The Client', an evil government minister funding inter-genetic time travel experiments. The same year she played Dr. Minny Stinkler in the comedy film ''[[Mad Cows]]'', directed by [[Sara Sugarman]]. In 1993 Scales voiced Mrs Tiggy-Winkle in [[The World of Peter Rabbit and Friends]]. In 2000 she appeared in the film ''[[The Ghost of Greville Lodge]]'' as Sarah. In 2003, she appeared as Hilda, "she who must be obeyed", wife of [[Rumpole of the Bailey|Horace Rumpole]] in four BBC Radio 4 plays, with Timothy West playing her fictional husband. Scales and West toured Australia at the same time in different productions. Scales appeared in a one-woman show called "''An Evening with [[Queen Victoria]]''", which also featured the tenor [[Ian Partridge]] singing songs written by [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]]. Also in 2003, she voiced the speaking ("cawing") role of Magpie, the eponymous thief in a recording of [[Gioachino Rossini]]'s opera ''[[La gazza ladra]]'' (The Thieving Magpie). In 2006, she appeared alongside [[Academy Award]] winners [[Vanessa Redgrave]] and [[Maximilian Schell]] in the mini-series ''[[The Shell Seekers (film)|The Shell Seekers]]''. On 16 November 2007, Scales appeared in ''[[Children in Need]]'', reprising her role as Sybil Fawlty, the new manager who wants to take over [[Hotel Babylon]]. She appeared in the audio play ''The Youth of Old Age'', produced in 2008 by the [[Wireless Theatre Company]], and available to download free of charge on their website.{{cite web |url= http://www.wirelesstheatrecompany.co.uk/product/the-youth-of-old-age/ |title=The Youth of Old Age |work=Wireless Theatre Company |year=2015 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} She appeared in a production of ''[[Carrie's War]]'', the [[Nina Bawden]] novel, at the [[Apollo Theatre]] in 2009.{{cite web|url=https://officiallondontheatre.com/news/scales-joins-carries-war-in-west-end-104621/|title=Scales joins Carrie’s War in West End|last=|first=|date=6 March 2009|work=OfficialLondonTheatre.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=31 October 2017}} In 2008, she appeared in [[Agatha Christie]]'s, ''[[A Pocket Full of Rye]]'', as Mrs. Mackenzie. [[John Cleese]] said in an interview on 8 May 2009 that the role of Sybil Fawlty was originally offered to [[Bridget Turner]], who turned down the part, claiming "it wasn't right for her".{{cite news |url= https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/fawlty-towers-almost-didnt-happen-for-prunella-392796 |title=Fawlty Towers almost didn't happen for Prunella Scales, according to John Cleese |work=[[Daily Mirror]] |date=8 May 2009 |publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=9975-9950 |oclc=223228477 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} She starred in the 2011 British live-action [[3D film|3D]] family comedy film ''[[Horrid Henry: The Movie]]'' as the titular character's Great Aunt Greta. Prunella Scales appeared in a short audio story, ''Dandruff Hits the Turtleneck'', written by John Mayfield, and available for download.{{cite web |url= http://www.audible.com/pd/Fiction/Dandruff-Hits-The-Turtleneck-Audiobook/B004LNS5H2 |title=Dandruff Hits The Turtleneck Audiobook |work=audible.com |year=2015 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} She starred in a Virgin Short "Stranger Danger" alongside Roderick Cowie in 2012.{{cite web |url= http://www.strangerdangershort.co.uk/?page_id=2 |title=Credits |work=Strangerdangershort.co.uk |year=2015 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} In 2013 she made a guest appearance in the popular BBC radio comedy ''[[Cabin Pressure (radio series)|Cabin Pressure]]'' as Wendy Crieff, the mother of Captain Martin Crieff. Alongside husband Timothy West, she has appeared in ''[[Great Canal Journeys]]'' for Channel 4. Stuart Heritage, writing for ''The Guardian'' in November 2016, commented that it "is ultimately a work about a devoted couple facing something huge together. It’s a beautiful, meditative programme".{{cite news|last=Heritage|first=Stuart|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/nov/07/great-canal-journeys-prunella-scales-timothy-west|title='It's like glimpsing an old couple holding hands': why I adore Great Canal Journeys|work=The Guardian|date=7 November 2016|accessdate=4 December 2016}} ==Personal life== Scales is married to the actor [[Timothy West]], with whom she has two sons; the elder is actor and director [[Samuel West]]. She also has a step daughter, Juliet, by West's first marriage. Her biography, ''Prunella'', written by Teresa Ransom, was published by John Murray in 2005.{{cite book |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Prunella-Authorised-Biography-Scales/dp/071955697X |title=Prunella: The Authorised Biography of Prunella Scales |first=Teresa |last=Ransom |location=London, UK |publisher=John Murray |year=2005 |isbn=9780719556975 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} She was appointed a [[Order of the British Empire|Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the [[1992 Birthday Honours]] List. Her husband received the same honour in the [[1984 Birthday Honours]] List. ===Other activities=== Scales is an ambassador of [[SOS Children's Villages]] charity.{{cite web |url=http://www.soschildrensvillages.org.uk/sos-childrens-charity/our-friends/|title=Our friends |work=soschildrensvillages.org.uk |accessdate=21 July 2015}} an international orphan charity providing homes and mothers for orphaned and abandoned children. She supports the charity's annual World Orphan Week campaign, which takes place each February.{{cite web |url=http://www.soschildren.org |title=SOS Children: Sponsor a child with our charity |work=soschildren.org |accessdate=21 July 2015}} Scales is a patron of the [[Lace Market Theatre]] in [[Nottingham]].{{cite web |url= http://lacemarkettheatre.co.uk/LaceMarketTheatre.dll/UserDefined?PageName=0&SubPageName=4 |title=Patrons |work=The Lace Market Theatre |year=2015 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} In 2005, she named the [[P&O Cruises|P&O]] cruise ship, ''Artemis''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pocruises.com/pocruising/learnmore-artemis-ship-statistics.aspx |work=P&O Cruises |title=Artemis |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505125104/http://www.pocruises.com/pocruising/learnmore-artemis-ship-statistics.aspx |archivedate=5 May 2008 }} ===Later life=== In January 2013, Scales told the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' that her short term memory was fading. In addition, she could not remember the year of birth of her two sons, nor when she and Timothy West married.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2271496/Richard-Briers-battling-chronic-lung-disease--lifelong-friend-Prunella-Scales-shocking-confession-own.html|title=Richard Briers battling chronic lung disease... as lifelong friend Prunella Scales has shocking confession of her own - Daily Mail Online|work=Mail Online}} In March 2014, her husband told ''[[The Guardian]]'' that Scales was living with [[Alzheimer's disease]].{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/mar/04/prunella-scales-suffering-mild-alzheimers |title=Prunella Scales suffering from 'a sort of mild Alzheimer's' |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=4 March 2014 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} The couple discussed practical measures in a radio programme about age and dementia on [[BBC Radio 4]] in December 2014. In August 2015, it was reported that Scales's condition had worsened considerably to the point that she can barely remember any of her fifty-three years of marriage to West.{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04v383w |title=Suppose I Lose It |work=BBC Radio 4 |year=2015 |accessdate=21 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3209629/Prunella-Scales-s-dementia-bad-forgot-d-just-seen.html|title=Prunella Scales's dementia is so bad she forgot show she'd just seen|work=Mail Online| accessdate= 20 February 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *{{IMDb name|768795}} *{{Screenonline name|567279}} *{{IBDB name}} *{{cite web |url= http://www.fawltysite.net/people/sybil_fawlty.htm |title=Sybil Fawlty played by Prunella Scales |work=fawltysite.net |year=2013 |accessdate=21 July 2015}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=President of the
