[http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=8 Results of the Eurovision Song Contest 2004]</ref> holding the title of [[People's Artist of Ukraine]].<ref name="Welcome to Ukraine">{{cite web|url=http://www.wumag.kiev.ua/index2.php?param=pgs20042/107|title=Ukrainian singer wins the Eurovision Song Contest|date=3 June 2004|publisher=Welcome to Ukraine|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref> She is also a former [[member of parliament|MP]] serving as deputy in the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] parliament ([[Verkhovna Rada]]) for the [[Our Ukraine (political party)|Our Ukraine Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.for-ua.com/news/2006/03/29/114013.html|title=Ruslana is ready to take her seat in the Parliament|date=29 March 2006|publisher=for-ua.com|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref> Ruslana was the [[List of UNICEF Goodwill Ambassadors|UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador]] in Ukraine in 2004-2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osce.org/cthb/46605|title=Ukrainian Eurovision winner Ruslana to back OSCE anti-trafficking campaign|date=14 June 2013|publisher=OSCE|accessdate=14 June 2013}}</ref> She is recognized as the most successful Ukrainian female solo artist internationally<ref name="UkrWeekly">{{cite web|url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2004/420429.shtml|title=Ruslana among winners at World Music Awards in Las Vegas|date=14 December 2004|publisher=UkrWeekly|accessdate=14 December 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nowtoronto.com/music/story.cfm?content=166018|title=Welcome the Ukrainian Madonna|date=14 November 2008|publisher=NowToronto}}</ref> and was included in the top 10 most influential women of 2013 by the [[Forbes]] magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forbes.ru/forbes-woman-photogallery/zhenshchiny-v-biznese/249077-zhenshchiny-goda-2013-reiting-forbes-woman/photo/5|title=Forbes: Most successful women of 2013|date=1 January 2014|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=1 January 2014}}</ref> The [[U.S. Secretary of State]] honored her with the [[International Women of Courage Award]] in March 2014.<ref name="Yahoo News">{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/ruslana-woman-courage-international-pop-star-former-ukraine-144500462.html|title=Ruslana - Woman of Courage, International Pop Star, Former Ukraine Parliament Member and EuroMaidan Protest Leader - to Discuss Current Crisis at National Press Club|publisher=Yahoo News|accessdate=3 March 2014}}</ref> She has been named an honorary citizen of her hometown [[L'viv]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kp.ua/culture/451043-vo-lvove-pevytsa-ruslana-stala-pochetnym-hrazhdanynom-horoda|title=Lviv singer Ruslana became an honorary citizen of the city|publisher=kp.ua|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref> and was nominated to receive the title [[Hero of Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zik.ua/ru/news/2014/04/01/na_lvovshchyne_deputati_hotyat_chtobi_ruslana_lizhychko_stala_geroem_ukrayni_475571|title=Lviv MP wants to name Ruslana Hero of Ukraine|publisher=zik.ua|accessdate=1 April 2014}}</ref>
She is a singer, songwriter, producer, musical conductor, [[multi-instrumentalist]], dancer, voice actress and [[social activist]]. She writes, composes and produces her own songs and music videos. Since 28 December 1995 she has been married to [[Oleksandr Ksenofontov]], a Ukrainian record producer.<ref name="Ruslana's husband speaks out">{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/2803/ruslanas_husband_speaks_out/|title=Ruslana's husband speaks out|date=24 May 2004|publisher=Esctoday.com|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref> Together they have run the company ''Luxen Studio'' since 1993, producing radio and film trailers.<ref name="Ruslana's husband speaks out"/>
Ruslana was the first artist from the former [[Soviet Union]] to officially receive a [[platinum disc]], her ''[[Dyki tantsi]]'' album selling more than 170,000 copies in the first 100 days after its release.<ref name="Ruslana Dyki Tantsi 2003">{{cite web|url=http://compmusic.kiev.ua/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=74&Itemid=11&lang=en |title=Ruslana "Dyki Tantsi" 2003 |date=3 October 2003 |publisher=for-ua.com |accessdate=27 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202230640/http://compmusic.kiev.ua/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=74&Itemid=11&lang=en |archivedate=2 December 2013 }}</ref> This album is the best selling [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] album to date, together with its English version, more than 500,000 copies being sold solely in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prlog.org/10875041-ruslana-international-pop-stareurovision-winner-returns-to-usa-with-concert.html|title=Ruslana, International pop star, Eurovision winner returns to USA with concert|date=20 August 2010|publisher=prlog.org|accessdate=22 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://files.korrespondent.net/projects/top100/2005/1063|title=60th Most Influential Person in Ukraine in 2005|date=10 January 2006|publisher=[[Korrespondent]]|accessdate=10 January 2006}}</ref>
She won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004|2004 Eurovision Song Contest]] with the song "[[Wild Dances]]" receiving 280 points, which at that time was a record of points.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/ukraines-ruslana-wins-eurovision-song-contest/231001.html|title=Ukraine's Ruslana wins Eurovision Song Contest|date=17 May 2004|publisher=The Moscow Times|accessdate=17 May 2004}}</ref> Following her victory, she rose to fame in Europe and became one of the biggest pop stars from the [[Eastern Europe|Eastern part of the continent]]. Her winning song "Wild Dances" dominated the European charts for 97 weeks peaking at number one in [[Belgium]] for 10 consecutive weeks.<ref name="ESCToday">{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/2970/ruslana_my_first_victory_after_eurovision/|title=Ruslana: My first victory after Eurovision...|date=14 July 2004|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=14 July 2004}}</ref> Her Eurovision winning song was included on the official compilation album called ''The Very Best of Eurovision'' celebrating the 60th anniversary of the contest.<ref name="SBS">{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/shop/product/category/Music/11241/Very-Best-of-Eurovision-Song-Contest-A-60th-Anniversary-CD-Digital-Download-PPSB#overview|title=Very Best of Eurovision Song Contest - A 60th Anniversary (CD / Digital Download Available NOW)|date=1 May 2015|publisher=SBS.au|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref>
Her repertoire includes songs performed mainly in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] and [[English language|English]], but she also recorded cover versions in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Latin language|Latin]] languages.
==Early life== Ruslana was born on 24 May 1973 in [[Lviv]], [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukraine]] to [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] father Stepan Lyzhychko and [[Russians|Russian]] mother Nina Sapegina.<ref name="gazeta.ua">{{cite web|url=http://gazeta.ua/ru/post/137468|title=Руслана Лыжичко пошла в бабушку|publisher= Gazeta.ua|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CY2TuWiN?url=http://gazeta.ua/ru/post/137468|archivedate=29 November 2012}}</ref> She was raised in the [[Lviv Oblast]] ([[oblast|province]]). Encouraged by her mother, Ruslana studied from the age of four at an experimental musical school and sang in different bands, including in the vocal-instrumental band Horizon, the band Orion and the children's ensemble Smile. After finishing secondary school, Ruslana entered the [[Lviv Conservatory]] where she graduated as a classical pianist and symphonic orchestra conductor in 1995.<ref name="ruslana.ua">{{cite web|url= http://www.ruslana.ua/en/bio.php|title=Biography on Ruslana's official website|accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref>
==Musical career==
===Early career=== Ruslana started her career as the winner of the [[Slavianski Bazaar in Vitebsk|Slavianski Bazaar]] song competition in Vitebsk, [[Belarus]] in 1996 with the song ''Oj, letili dyki husi''.<ref name="ruslana.ua"/> In the same year, she was among the nominees for the Ukrainian Singer of the Year award and the video for ''Dzvinkyi Viter'' (''Wind Bells'') was awarded Music Video of the Year. Since her early career, Ruslana's producer was Oleksandr Ksenofontov, whom she married in 1995.<ref>[http://ukrfoto.net/people_12.html Знаменитості України: Лижичко Руслана Степанівна (співачка)]</ref>
In 1997, Ruslana began working on ''Christmas with Ruslana'' – the first [[L'viv]] Christmas television project of an All-Ukrainian scale including the video clip ''Ballad of a Princess'' which was the first animated music video made by a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] singer.
Her first album ''[[Myt Vesny – Dzvinkyi Viter]]'' (''A Moment of Spring – Wind Bells''), released in 1998, received high praise from the critics.
Still, wider recognition did not come until 1998 with the song ''Svitanok'' (''Sunrise'') and the album ''Myt' Vesny – Dzvinkyj Viter Live''. ''Svitanok'' was the first Ukrainian big-budget music video. In 1998, Ruslana was awarded Person of the Year, the song ''Svitanok'' was awarded Song of the Year and its accompanying music video was awarded Music Video of the Year. In the second half of 1998, she organized a charity tour which had the aim of raising funds for the restoration of the old castles from Western Ukraine. The tour was a success and thanks to Ruslana's efforts, the [[Zolochiv Castle]] was restored.<ref>[http://www.day.kiev.ua/en/article/culture/who-will-save-ukrainian-castles Who will Save Ukrainian Castles?]</ref>
In 1999, she worked on the Christmas musical ''Ostanne rizdvo 90th'' (''The Last Christmas of the 90s''), which won the Ukrainian ''Movie of the Year'' award. With the video clip to the song ''Znaju ya'' (''I Know''), which is about the ancient people of the [[Hutsuls]] living in the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[Carpathians]], Ruslana set new standards for modern video clip filming.
===Education=== [[File:Ruslana conducting the orchestra.jpg|thumb|Ruslana is one of the very few pop singers who are capable of conducting a symphonic orchestra, thanks to her higher education in music.]] In 1995, Ruslana graduated from the [[Lviv Conservatory]] as professional conductor and classical pianist. She was the student of one of the most prominent [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] composers and conductors, [[Mykola Kolessa]] who is regarded as 'the father of the Ukrainian conducting school'. She used to be a part of the student choir of the Lviv Music Academy.
===2004: Wild Dances Project and Eurovision victory=== [[File:Ruslana Eurovision 2005 final.jpg|thumb|Ruslana performing "[[Heart on Fire (Ruslana song)|Heart on Fire]]" at the opening of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005]].]]
====Wild Dances Project==== Ruslana's father is from the West-Ukrainian area of the [[Hutsuls]], the dwellers of the Ukrainian Carpathian Mountains. They have a unique culture with an ancient and rich history which inspired Ruslana to create her concept album ''Wild Dances''. It combines powerful and permeating ethnic drums, trumpet sounds of the [[trembita]], an ancient [[Hutsul]] music instrument, with modern dance beats. The album was composed by Ruslana after an expedition to the [[Carpathian Mountains]] in spring 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wumag.kiev.ua/index2.php?param=pgs20043/4|title=Ruslana – the first Ukrainian pop singer to win a major European pop song contest|date=3 June 2004|publisher=Welcome to Ukraine|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref>
The album ''Dyki Tantsi'' (''Wild Dances'') was released in June 2003 in [[Ukraine]]. The album sold more than 170,000 copies in the first 100 days after its release, even without a supporting tour.<ref name="Ruslana Dyki Tantsi 2003"/> Together with its English language counterpart it was the first album ever to be certified five times platinum in Ukraine, selling more than 500,000 copies, making it the most successful album in Ukraine ever.<ref name="ruslana.ua"/>
====Eurovision Song Contest 2004==== {{main|Eurovision Song Contest 2004}} Ruslana was internally chosen by the [[National Television Company of Ukraine|NTU]] to represent [[Ukraine]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004]]. Before the contest, she was a hot favorite for victory by the bookmakers. At the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004]], she performed her self-composed song, ''[[Wild Dances]]'' and won the contest receiving 280 points. In the semifinal, the song received points from all other participating countries; in the final, Switzerland was the only country not giving any points to the song.
The single ''Wild Dances'' stayed a total of 97 weeks in various European single charts. It was certified gold in Belgium, Sweden, Russia, Greece, the Czech Republic and Slovakia. In Belgium it topped the single charts at #1 for 10 consecutive weeks. Also in Ukraine and Greece the song peaked at #1.<ref name="ESCToday"/> The English language album ''Wild Dances'' was released in many European countries in the autumn of 2004. In [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] she received the [[World Music Awards|World Music Award]] as best selling Ukrainian artist.<ref name="UkrWeekly"/>
After her victory Ruslana was appointed advisor to the Ukrainian prime minister, and the Ukrainian president bestowed upon her one of the country's highest honors when she received the title of [[People's Artist of Ukraine]].<ref name="Welcome to Ukraine"/>
In Belgium she was among the top 15 ranked performers with her singles "[[Wild Dances (song)|Wild Dances]]" and "[[Dance with the Wolves]]".<ref name="Ukraine All About">{{cite web|url=http://ukraineallaboutu.com/travel-in-ukraine/meet-people/#/ruslana/|title=Meet world famous Ukrainian celebrities Shevchenko, Klitschko and Ruslana|date=14 July 2012|publisher=Ukraine All About|accessdate=9 July 2013}}</ref> Ruslana was named the most popular person in [[Belgium]],<ref name="Ukraine All About"/> the sexiest girl in [[Greece]],<ref name="Ukraine All About"/> the most influential public person in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="Ukraine All About"/> and was the first foreigner to receive the award of the Federation of Journalists in [[Turkey]].<ref name="Ukraine All About"/>
===2005=== {{main|Eurovision Song Contest 2005}} [[File:Ruslana Ukrainian stamp 2005-2.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian stamp celebrating Ruslana's victory at the Eurovision Song Contest]] Ruslana had been initially chosen to host the semi final and the grand final of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005]].<ref name="ruslana">{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/4368|title=Ruslana resigns as host|last=Bakker|first=Sietse|date=4 May 2005|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref> However, the singer had to decline the offer due to her involvement in the organization of a big charity concert dedicated to the victims of the [[Chernobyl disaster]]. Therefore, Ruslana appeared at the event only as a guest star. She performed a medley of ''[[Wild Dances (song)|Wild Dances]]'' and ''Heart on Fire'' at the opening ceremony being accompanied by the Zhyttia ballet and the Ukrainian drums ensamble ARS Nova. After interviewing the competitors in the [[green room]] she also performed her latest single ''[[The Same Star]]''. During this performance Ruslana wore a red costume inspired by Ukrainian ethnic elements.
Also in 2005, Ruslana designed the cover for [[Jonathan Safran Foer]]'s ''The Unabridged Pocket Book of Lightning'' which was produced as part of [[Penguin Books]]' 70th birthday celebrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bookcoverarchive.com/book/the_unabridged_pocketbook_of_lightning|title=Book cover archive|date=5 June 2005|publisher=bookcoverarchieve.com|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref>
===2006=== {{main|Best of Eurovision}} Ruslana's song ''[[Wild Dances]]'' was named the [[Best of Eurovision]] in an internet voting arranged by the German public television broadcaster [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]]. During the television program ''Grand Prix Hitliste'', ''[[Wild Dances]]'' was presented as the winner, ahead of famous songs, such as ''[[Waterloo (ABBA song)|Waterloo]]'' and Germany's only winner (at the time), ''[[Ein Bißchen Frieden]]'', which finished sixth and twelfth, respectively. The programme was viewed by a television audience of approximately six million people in Germany.<ref name="ruslana2">{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/6210|title=Ruslana – The best of Eurovision|author=Busa, Alexandru|publisher=esctoday|date=4 July 2007|accessdate=24 May 2006}}</ref>
For the [[FIFA World Cup 2006]] Ruslana went on tour in Germany to support the [[Ukrainian national football team]]. She performed in [[Hamburg]], [[Cologne]], Berlin, [[Leipzig]], and [[Nuremberg]].
===2008: Wild Energy & ''Grand Theft Auto IV''===
Ruslana's project ''Wild Energy'' was based on the science fiction novel by Maryna and Sergij Diachenko ''[[Wild Energy. Lana]]''. In a future city which experiences a global energy crisis, far more threatening than lack of oil and gas, people are lacking their will to live, their energy of the heart – the "fuel for people". Lana, one of the synthetic inhabitants, sets out to find the mystical energy source. After many adventures she discovers that the wild energy comes from her own heart. [[Wild Energy (album)|Wild Energy]] combines the art of music and video production, literature and social commitment in an extraordinary way. In June 2006 Ruslana presented the new single and video ''[[Wild Energy (song)|Wild Energy]]'' in a unique fantasy style. In this video clip the singer develops from a synthetic blonde girl into her wild image.
In March 2008 Ruslana's Ukrainian album ''[[Amazonka]]'' was released in Ukraine, Czech Republic and Slovakia. The English album ''[[Wild Energy (album)|Wild Energy]]'' was released by [[Warner Music]] in Canada and several European countries in autumn 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/10527/ruslana_sings_major_recording_deal_with_warner_records/|title=Ruslana signs major recording deal with Warner Records|date=15 February 2008|publisher=EscToday.com|accessdate=15 February 2008}}</ref>
The album was recorded at the [[Hit Factory]] Studio in Miami and contains two collaborations with American Urban superstars [[T-Pain]] and [[Missy Elliott]].<ref>[http://blog.ruslana.ua/?p=377&language=en Ruslana to release Wild Energy]</ref> On this release Ruslana creates her own distinctive technique of incorporating ancient ethnic styles of the [[Carpathian Mountain]] people with modern popular music.
In ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'', Ruslana lends her voice as the host of [[Vladivostok FM]]. Her song "[[Wild Dances]]" is featured as one of the songs on Vladivostok. On 13 May 2008, ''Grand Theft Auto IV'' broke the [[Guinness World Records]] for "Highest grossing video game in 24 hours" and "Highest Revenue Generated by an Entertainment Product in 24 Hours". It sold 3.6 million copies on day one generating $310 million in revenue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/05/13/grand-theft-auto-iv-breaks-guinness-world-records-with-biggest-entertainment-release-of-all-time|title=Grand Theft Auto IV breaks Guinness World Records with biggest entertainment release of all-time|date=13 May 2008|publisher=ign.com|accessdate=12 June 2014}}</ref>
===2009–2010: Asia Song Festival & new album recordings=== [[File:Ruslana in 2009 Asia Song Festival.jpg|thumb|Ruslana on the catwalk of the 2009 [[Asia Song Festival]] in [[Seoul]], [[Korea]]]] In 2009, she was invited to attend the sixth [[Asia Song Festival]] which took place in [[Seoul]], [[Korea]]. The event was held at the [[Seoul World Cup Stadium]] where Ruslana sung in front of an audience of 60,000 people. Together with the ''Zhyttia'' ballet, she performed three songs from her first international album: "[[Wild Dances]]", "[[Dance with the Wolves]]" and a bilingual version of "Play, Musician!". Her act was met with great enthusiasm by the Asian public who didn't know her until that moment. Even if she was supposed to receive only an award for her contribution to the cultural exchange between Ukraine and Asia in music, in the end she also won the main award of the festival, receiving the golden statue for the best artist of the Asia Song Festival 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=4283|title=Ruslana conquered Asian hearts|date=22 September 2009|publisher=eurovision.tv|accessdate=12 June 2014}}</ref>
===2011–2012: The Voice of Ukraine and Ukrainian album ''Ey-fori-YA''=== In 2011, Ruslana was appointed as one of the judges of the Ukrainian version of ''[[The Voice (TV series)|The Voice]]'' show. Her involvement in the project was featured on the Dutch TV where the original show of the series kicked off. Eventually, Ruslana's alumni, Tonya Matvienko, placed 2nd in the grand final of the Ukrainian show.
Also in 2011, her song ''[[Wild Dances (song)|Wild Dances]]'' was used by the American gymnast [[Jordyn Wieber]] as the soundtrack for her floor exercise.<ref name="ESPN">{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/espnw/news-commentary/article/7096506/jordyn-wieber-wins-world-gymnastics-all-title|title=Jordyn Wieber wins world all-around title|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref> Wieber eventually became the 2011 [[2011 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships|World Women's All-Around Champion]] and won the golden medal at the [[Gymnastics at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Women's artistic team all-around|2012 Summer Olympics]] performing her floor exercise on Ruslana's song.<ref name="ESPN"/>
In April 2012 the new Ukrainian language album ''ЕЙ-форі-Я'' (''EY-fori-YA'') was released in Ukraine. The album on which Ruslana had worked for four years was produced in the USA, Sweden and Ukraine produced by [[Vlad (musician)|Vlad Debriansky]] and Ruslana and features musicians such as Rusty Allen, Victor Little, George Benson, Brian Coller and others.<ref name="umka.com.ua">[http://www.umka.com.ua/eng/catalogue/dance-pop/ruslana-ey-fori-ya-eu-phori-a.html Ruslana. HEY-phori-YEAH. (EU-phori-A)]</ref>
Despite its intercontinental rock and pop nature, the album ''EY-fori-YA'' and the three songs taken from it previously is based on Slavic rhythms. Ruslana integrated old Slavic circle dances, liturgies and elements of classic pieces of Russian composers including [[Mikhail Glinka|Glinka]], [[Tschaikowsky]], [[Mussorgsky]], and [[Rachmaninow]].<ref name="umka.com.ua"/> The album is designed for flash mob type synchronous dances. In April/May 2012 she toured 11 Ukrainian cities with a unique show concept called ''OGO Show''. During these open-air events Ruslana appeared as lead dancer teaching the audience the moves. The audience doesn't consume passively, but is integrated into the show.<ref>[http://www.ogoshow.com.ua Ogoshow] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120803042756/http://ogoshow.com.ua/ |date=3 August 2012 }}</ref> More concept concerts followed within the framework of the ''EURO 2012'' public fan events.
===2013: International album ''My Boo! (Together!)'' & ''Clash of the Choirs''=== Her third international album was set to be released in 2013 under the title ''[[My Boo (Ruslana album)|My Boo! (Together!)]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perfecte.ro/international/ti-o-mai-amintesti-pe-ruslana-castigatoarea-eurovisionului-din-2004-vezi-cum-arata-acum-la-40-de-ani.html|title=Ti-o mai amintesti pe Ruslana?|publisher=perfecte.ro|accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref> The new material shows how versatile Ruslana is as an artist as she completely changed her style since the ''[[Wild Energy (album)|Wild Energy]]'' project, from a wild [[Amazons|Amazon]] to a Urban pop princess.
Most of the album was produced by [[Vlad (musician)|Vlad DeBriansky]] in Los Angeles and includes the names of American top musicians such as [[Rusty Allen]], Victor Little, [[Oscar Seaton, Jr.|Oscar Seaton]], Brian Coller as well as [[Stefan Örn]] from [[Sweden]] who won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011]] as a songwriter. [[Goran Bregovich]], the legendary [[Balkan]] musician from [[Serbia]] produced the song ''Kray''<ref>[http://www.umka.com.ua/eng/catalogue/dance-pop/ruslana-ey-fori-ya-eu-phori-a.html UMKA : Ruslana. HEY-phori-YEAH. (EU-phori-A)]</ref>
At the same time of the release of the new English album Ruslana's Ukrainian album ''ЕЙ-форі-Я'' (''EY-fori-YA'', ''Euphoria'') was re-released under the new title ''Мій Брат! (разом)'' (''Miy Brat! (razom!)'', ''My Brother! (together!)''). The renaming of the album had become necessary because of the coincidental same name of the winning song of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2012]]. The Swedish singer [[Loreen (singer)|Loreen]] won the event with the song ''Euphoria'', one month after Ruslana had released her Ukrainian album and song of the same name. In order to avoid misunderstandings Ruslana's renamed not only her album but also her English song ''Euphoria'' into ''This Is Euphoria''.<ref>{{YouTube|iZbREPPVRYI|Interview Ruslana – My boo! (World Out Games 2013 – Antwerp – Belgium)}}</ref>
In August 2013 Ruslana globally released the single ''This Is Euphoria'' digitally. The track was composed and produced by Ruslana and the Swedish musician [[Stefan Örn]].
She was invited to perform at the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2013]] which took place in her country's capital [[Kiev]].<ref>[http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=remarkable_ruslana_to_perform_with_a_childrens_choir_at_the_junior_eurovision_song_contest Remarkable Ruslana to perform with a children's choir at the Junior Eurovision Song Contest]</ref> Nevertheless, she withdrew her act from the show considering the violence shown by the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] authorities against [[2013 Ukraine pro-European Union protests|those who were peacefully protesting]] in the country's capital.<ref>[http://escreporter.com/why-wasnt-ruslana-at-junior-eurovision/ Why wasn't Ruslana at Junior Eurovision? ]</ref>
She was one of the coaches of the first season of the [[Clash of the Choirs]] TV show in [[Ukraine]]. Ruslana and her alumni from the city of [[Lviv]] have won the grand final of the project on 5 January 2014, receiving 78% of the tele voting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1plus1.ua/novyny/ruslana-rozridalasya-na-sceni-bitvi-horiv-pochuvshi-pro-peremogu-svoyeyi-komandi-328407.html |title=Руслана розридалася на сцені "Битви хорів", почувши про перемогу своєї команди - Новини |publisher=1plus1.ua |date= |accessdate=2014-06-06}}</ref>
===2014–2016: Eurovision juror=== In January 2014 her international album ''[[My Boo (Ruslana album)|My Boo! (Together!)]]'' was released digitally. For her subsequent album Ruslana intended to study again [[ethnic]] motifs as she regarded the [[Wild Dances (song)|Wild Dances]] project as her most creative work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://show.obozrevatel.com/article/50138-ruslana-myi-s-muzhem-sozdanyi-drug-dlya-druga.htm|title=Ruslana: My s muzhem sozdany drug dlya druga|work=Obozrevatel.com|accessdate=7 June 2013}}</ref> Due to her active involvement in the [[Euromaidan]] in Ukraine, Ruslana had to postpone her musical plans.
Ruslana was invited as music expert for Eurosong, the [[Belgium in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014|Belgian selection for the 2014 Eurovision Song Contest]] in order to choose the best candidate to represent Belgium at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.escflashmalta.com/index.php/music-news/international-music-news/item/3301-belgium-ruslana-joins-panel-for-eurosong-2014|title=Belgium: Ruslana Joins Panel for Eurosong 2014|work=ESCflashMalta.com|accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref>
On 9 and 10 October Ruslana held two concerts at the Manchester Ukrainian Cultural Centre 'Dnipro'. She originally planned on performing only one show however as the tickets sold out within hours, it was decided that she would perform a second concert the next day. Tickets for that show were also almost sold out.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ruslana.ua/ua/news.php?id=6253|title=Два надзвичайних живих концерти в Манчестері|accessdate=25 October 2015}}</ref>
On 24 October, Ruslana performed a concert along with the [[Ukrainian Bandurist Chorus]] in [[Massey Hall]] in [[Toronto]]. The purpose of the concert was to showcase the beauty and the importance of the [[Bandura]] in Ukrainian music and culture. For her final song, Ruslana performed along with the Ukrainian Bandurist Chorus as well as the Zoloti Struny Youth Bandura Ensemble based in Toronto. Ruslana was a juror for the [[Ukraine in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016|Ukrainian national final]] for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]]. Out of the three jury members, she was the only one who supported the singer [[Jamala]] who later on became the second Eurovision winner from [[Ukraine]].
In late 2016, after Jamala's victory at Eurovision in Stockholm, Ruslana played 3 concerts in Western Europe. In October she played in London, in November she played in Paris and in December she played in Hanover (Hannover). In all of these concerts she spoke about the victory that Jamala brought for Ukraine, and how Ukraine would be opening up to the world again in May 2017.
=== 2017: It's Magical / Ya lyublyu === After her long-lasting creative break, which was caused by the dramatic and stormy events in Ukraine, Ruslana presented her new single "It's Magical / Я люблю" at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|Eurovision]] Grand Finale in Kyiv on 13 May 2017. The new music style combines tender cradle songs with brisk exotic melodies and rhythms. The original, exotic manner of singing which forms the basis of the soundtrack Ruslana acquired on sometimes extreme expeditions into the Carpathian Mountains. The song was released in an English ("It's Magical") and a Ukrainian version ("Я люблю" / "Ya lyublyu" / "I Love").<ref>{{cite web|url= https://oikotimes.com/2017/05/18/ruslana-releases-brand-new-single-and-video-because-its-magical/ |title= Ruslana releases brand new single and video "It's Magical" |publisher=Oikotimes |date=2017-05-18 |accessdate=2017-05-21}}</ref>
The film production took place in a unique place, the Basalt quarry in the [[Rivne]] region. Director [[Oles Sanin]] created a thunder storm in a realistic way for the video clip. The image of Ruslana in the chainmail in which she appears in the clip resembles her internal state. After all the events in her country and her extreme expeditions into the mountains, Ruslana feels like a kind of warrioress who is called to protect the most valuable: Love. In her song, video Ruslana wants to draw attention to the widespread deforestation in the Carpathians. Her aim is the preservation of the Carpathian primeval forests, their unique wildlife, and exceptional culture.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://oikotimes.com/2017/05/18/ruslana-releases-brand-new-single-and-video-because-its-magical/ |title= Ruslana releases brand new single and video "It's Magical" |publisher=Oikotimes |date=2017-05-18 |accessdate=2017-05-21}}</ref>
==Political activities==
===2004: Orange Revolution=== {{main|Orange Revolution}} In autumn 2004 Ruslana actively supported the democratic processes in Ukraine known as the [[Orange Revolution]], to which her song "[[Dance with the Wolves]]" was devoted. She declared her support for [[Viktor Yushchenko]] during the disputed [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|Ukrainian presidential elections]]. She became one of the prominent figures that addressed the mass crowds rallying in support of Yushchenko's demand that his original defeat be declared fraudulent. From spring 2006 to summer 2007 she was a Member of the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament]] for the party [[People's Union Our Ukraine|Our Ukraine]].<ref>[http://www.ruslana.com.ua/text/arch/eng/arch2007summer.html Ruslana resigns as Member of Parliament]</ref>
Due to political reasons the music video supporting her second single extracted from the ''[[Wild Dances]]'' album, "Dance with the Wolves" was censored in Russia as it contains fragments showing Ruslana in the Independence Square.<ref>[http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/3874 Ruslana censored in Russia]</ref>
Ruslana endorsed [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]]<ref>{{uk icon}} [http://pravda.com.ua/news/2009/6/26/97365.htm Руслана на виборах президента підтримає Тимошенко], [[Ukrainska Pravda]] (26 June 2009)</ref> and actively supported her candidature during the [[election campaign]].<ref>{{uk icon}} [http://pravda.com.ua/news/2009/9/10/101315.htm Зірковий колгосп для Тимошенко], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (10 September 2009)</ref><ref>[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-335965.html Best singers of country start tour in support of Tymoshenko], [[UNIAN]] (14 September 2009)</ref>
===2012: Campaign against judicial arbitrariness===
In December 2012 Ruslana launched the human rights campaign ''Не мовчи'' (''Don't keep silent'') which challenges the juridical system of Ukraine. In particular she supports the case of Dmytro and Sergiy Pavlichenko who claim to have been forced to admit a murder they have not committed. The father and son were convicted of killing a judge of a district court in Kyiv and sentenced to life imprisonment and 13 years in prison respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/132017.html |title= Ukrainian ombudsperson promises to check Pavlichenkos' claims of extorted confession to murder|publisher =Interfax Ukraine|date= 14 December 2012|accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref> The verdict was widely criticized mainly by football fans.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.theyarenotkillers.com|title=theyarenotkillers.com|accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref> Ruslana dedicated her song and video ''Це – Ей-форі-Я'' (''This is Euphoria'') to the case of the Pavlichenkos who according to her are victims of a misjudgement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=syGbUmsEI0M&list=UUwswva9TnLYr46Lm2rdyhmw|title=Ruslana's advocacy campaign "Don't Keep Silent", Press-center UNIAN|publisher=RuslanaTube|date=4 December 2012|accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref>
===2013–2014: Euromaidan=== {{see also|Euromaidan}}
[[File:Ruslana reading out an official resolution of Euromaidan.jpg|thumb|Ruslana reading out an official resolution of Euromaidan, 29 November 2013]] [[File:Ruslana in Brussels.JPG|thumb|Ruslana with [[José Manuel Barroso]] and Henri Malosse at the Plenary Session of the EESC in Brussels]] [[File:First Lady Michelle Obama and Deputy Secretary Higginbottom With 2014 IWOC Awardee Ruslana Lyzhychko of Ukraine (12935913344).jpg|thumbnail|First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] and Deputy Secretary [[Heather Higginbottom]] pose for a photo with 2014 Secretary of State's International Women of Courage Award Winner Ruslana]] Ruslana was one of the leading figures of the pro-EU protests known as [[Euromaidan]].<ref name="UW291113R&opub">[http://www.kyivpost.com/guide/about-kyiv/musicians-liven-up-euromaidan-stage-332611.html Musicians liven up EuroMaidan stage], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (29 November 2013) {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131129091452/http://www.kyivpost.com/guide/about-kyiv/musicians-liven-up-euromaidan-stage-332611.html |date=29 November 2013 }}</ref><ref name="bloomberg.com">{{cite news|title=Bershidsky on Europe: Swiss Reject Pay Cap|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-11-25/bershidsky-on-europe-swiss-reject-pay-cap.html|accessdate=25 November 2013|date=25 November 2013|agency=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|quote=Yet the Euromaidan, as the protest campaign is known, is serious enough to give President Viktor Yanukovych a serious scare.}}</ref><ref name="ukrainian.voanews.com">{{cite news|script-title=uk:"Євромайдан" вимагає скасування рішення уряду про відмову від євроінтеграції|url=http://ukrainian.voanews.com/content/ukrainian-euromaidan/1796743.html|accessdate=25 November 2013|agency=[[Voice of America]]: Ukrainian|language=uk}}</ref> On 22 November 2013, Ukrainian citizens started spontaneous protests in [[Kiev]], the capital of [[Ukraine]], after the Ukrainian government had suspended preparations for signing an [[Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement|Association Agreement]] with the [[European Union]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ukraine drops EU plans and looks to Russia|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/11/ukraine-drops-eu-plans-looks-russia-20131121145417227621.html|accessdate=24 November 2013|newspaper=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=21 November 2013}}</ref> {{external media | width = 210px | float = right | headerimage = [[File:Ruslana Euromaidan1.JPG|210px]] | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0H2-_lUIcI0 Ukrainian star & activist Ruslana speaks at the National Press Club], 5 March 2014, 1:09:44 | accessdate =6 January 2017 }}
From the first day of the protests she stayed on [[Kiev]]'s [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]] virtually all night, up to ten hours a night.<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/53812822/ns/world_news-europe/#.Uq8vxLTKlHU Ukrainian Eurovision pop star becomes voice of protest], [[NBCNews.com]] (12 December 2013)</ref><ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/ukraines-euromaidan-how-kiev-protests-reflect-ukraines-dance-between-east-west-1509144 Ukraine's EuroMaidan: How The Kiev Protests Reflect Ukraine's Dance Between East And West], ''[[International Business Times]]'' (13 December 2013)</ref> In an interview with [[The Daily Beast]] on 11 December 2013 she explained her role in the opposition as ''charging Maidan with freedom-loving energy'', insisted she ''hates'' politics<ref name="RuslanaTDBI111213">[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/12/11/meet-ruslana-lyzhychko-the-soulvoickraine-s-revolution.html Meet Ruslana Lyzhychko, the Soul of Ukraine's Revolution], [[The Daily Beast]] (11 December 2013)</ref> and denied supporting any single leader.<ref name=MrmcpYN131213>[http://uk.news.yahoo.com/eurovision-winner-sings-revolution-ukraine-174632324.html#AvyIJig Eurovision winner sings for revolution in Ukraine], [[Yahoo! News]] (13 December 2013)</ref>
In total Ruslana spent at least 100 days and 100 nights on the Maidan stage during the cold winter inspiring the crowds, giving speeches and singing the Ukrainian national anthem every hour day after day and night after and night, often sleeping just a couple of hours on the floor of the Trade Union building occupied by the protesters.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ruslana at John Batchelor Show, 7.4.2014 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v4X4r4OEDSU|accessdate=7 April 2014| date=7 April 2014}}</ref> As a symbol of people power, peace and freedom she established holding up flashlights while singing the Ukrainian national anthem.
When during the night of 30 November 2013 the riot police wanted to clear the occupied Maidan and started beating up peacefully sleeping activists Ruslana rushed for help and managed to seek shelter with about 100 students, some of them wounded, in a nearby monastery.<ref>{{cite news|title=Special police disrupts EuroMaidan|url= http://ukrainianweek.com/News/95319|accessdate=12 June 2014|newspaper=The Ukrainian Week|date=30 November 2013}}</ref> During another night in December 2013 when the riot police advanced again towards the square Ruslana did her utmost to deescalate the situation by talking to them from the stage repeating over and over again "Quiet! No violence!". She gave the protesters the courage to peacefully withstand more than 2,000 riot police who eventually retreated.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ruslana Honored with International Women of Courage Award|url= http://ukraine.usembassy.gov/statements/ruslana-03042014.html|accessdate=12 June 2014|newspaper=Embassy of the United States in Ukraine|date=4 March 2014}}</ref>
Her commitment in the pro-European movement was featured in many international publications. While the American press regarded her as the 'true heroine of [[Ukraine]]',<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet Ruslana Lyzhychko, the Soul of Ukraine's Revolution|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/12/11/meet-ruslana-lyzhychko-the-soulvoickraine-s-revolution.html|accessdate=11 December 2013|newspaper=Daily Beast|date=11 December 2013}}</ref> the [[German language|German]] magazine ''[[Der Spiegel|Spiegel]]'' called her 'Kiev's queen of the night',<ref>{{cite news|title= Revolutionssängerin Ruslana: Kiews Königin der Nacht|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/ukraine-saengerin-ruslana-stimmt-jede-nacht-die-nationalhymne-an-a-939391.html|accessdate=31 December 2013|newspaper=[[Der Spiegel|Spiegel]]|date=17 December 2013}}</ref> and the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] newspaper ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'' compared her to [[Jeanne d'Arc]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Ruslana, una indígena ucraniana por Europa|url=http://www.elmundo.es/loc/2013/12/09/52a2257e63fd3deb448b457e.html|accessdate=31 December 2013|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=9 December 2013}}</ref> The media even compared her to [[Katniss Everdeen]], the heroine of [[The Hunger Games]] trilogy.<ref>{{cite news|title=How Ukraine is like "The Hunger Games"|url=http://www.vocativ.com/01-2014/ukraine-like-hunger-games/|accessdate=7 January 2014|newspaper=Vocativ.com|date=7 January 2014}}</ref> The Russian ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine included her in the top 10 of the most influential women of 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forbes.ru/forbes-woman-photogallery/zhenshchiny-v-biznese/249077-zhenshchiny-goda-2013-reiting-forbes-woman/photo/10|title=Forbes: Most influential women of 2013|date=1 January 2014|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=1 January 2014}}</ref> and the ''Business Ukraine'' magazine named her 'person of the year'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bunews.com.ua/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1238:business-ukraine-magazine-person-of-the-year-ruslana&catid=6:politics&Itemid=2 |title=Person of the year: Ruslana |date=13 January 2014 |publisher=Business Ukraine |accessdate=13 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111153333/http://www.bunews.com.ua/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1238:business-ukraine-magazine-person-of-the-year-ruslana&catid=6:politics&Itemid=2 |archivedate=11 January 2014 }}</ref>
From January 2014 Ruslana started to meet with key EU and U.S. politicians asking for support for Ukraine. Her first appearance in this role at the 495th Plenary Session of the [[European Economic and Social Committee]] (EESC) and a meeting with [[José Manuel Barroso]], President of the European Commission, resulted in a resolution of the EESC to support the Ukrainian civil society and its democratic rights.<ref>{{cite news|title=The protest movement of Maidan in Kiev at the EESC|url=http://www.eesc.europa.eu/?i=president.en.my-news.30579|accessdate=25 January 2014|publisher=Website of the EESC}}</ref> In the following months Ruslana travelled to Stockholm, Paris, Warsaw, Brussels, Vienna, Strasbourg, Berlin, Munich, São Paulo, Washington D.C. and New York speaking to leading government officials demanding international support. In addition she gave the mass media in various countries an authentic view on the events in Ukraine.
Her activism put herself in serious danger. She received numerous death threats on her phone, her car was followed and she couldn't live in her house for several weeks because it was constantly observed. Snipers aimed at her while she was standing on the Maidan stage. The threats started after she started demanding sanctions from the EU governments against the [[Viktor Yanukovych|Yanukovych]] government.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://maidantranslations.com/2014/02/10/ruslana-titushky-banished-me-from-my-home-threaten-to-punish-me-like-bulatov/comment-page-1/|title=Ruslana: Titushky banished me from my home, threaten to punish me like Bulatov|date=9 February 2014|publisher= Pravda.com.ua|accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref> Ruslana had also noted the presence of paid provocateurs who have instigated fights in the otherwise peaceful protests.<ref>http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/euromaidan-rallies-in-ukraine-live-updates-332341.html</ref> After President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] had fled the country in late February 2014 and the fights in Ukraine escalated Ruslana targeted Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] as aggressor and demanded sanctions against him and his government. In Washington D.C. she stated: ''Putin's propaganda is a machine against the truth. Putin started his terrorist operation in Eastern Ukraine and is preparing his way to Kyiv. Russia's special forces, terrorist, are invading Ukraine. … Tomorrow we will wake up and see that Putin took away everything he wanted.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/en/news/transcripts/2014-distinguished-humanitarian-leadership-award-ruslana-lyzhychko|title=2014 Distinguished Humanitarian Leadership Award: Ruslana Lyzhychko |date=30 April 2014|publisher= Atlantic Council|accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref>
For her extraordinary courage, commitment and dedication Ruslana was honoured with several awards including the International Woman of Courage Award, awarded by First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] at the [[Woman in the World Summit]] in New York<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ilve2leadblogil2lorg.me/2014/04/08/international-woman-of-courage-ruslana-lyzhchko-of-the-ukraine/|title=International Woman of Courage: Ruslana Lyzhchko of the Ukraine|date=8 April 2014|publisher= Woman in the World Summit|accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref> and the 2014 [[Distinguished Humanitarian Leadership Award]] from at the [[Atlantic Council]] in Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/en/news/transcripts/2014-distinguished-humanitarian-leadership-award-ruslana-lyzhychko|title=2014 Distinguished Humanitarian Leadership Award: Ruslana Lyzhychko|date=30 April 2014|publisher=Atlantic Council|accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref>
On 24 May 2014, the day before the Presidential election in Ukraine which happened to be also her birthday, Ruslana organized a global joint prayer which involved one million people in several countries highlighting the unity of Ukrainians across the world and the global support for Ukraine. Ruslana herself read the prayer "For Ukraine, for peace and quiet" and performed the Ukrainian national anthem in 12 languages on Mount [[Khomyak]] in the [[Carpathian Mountains]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.768951153150053.1073741887.143316715713503&type=3|title=Ruslana with a million people around the world prayed for Ukraine|date=24 May 2014|publisher=Facebook RuslanaOfficial|accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref>
==Social commitment== In 2004-2005 Ruslana was appointed Good Will Ambassador of Ukraine by the [[UNICEF]] and combats [[trafficking in human beings]].<ref>[http://www.brama.com/news/press/2005/05/050510ruslana_unicef.html Ruslana becomes first ever UNICEF National Ambassador in Ukraine ]</ref> She released two video clips which aim to make potential victims aware of the dangers of [[human trafficking]]. In February 2008 Ruslana performed at an anti-human trafficking event in [[Vienna]], Austria, organized by [[UN.GIFT]] (The United Nations Global Initiative to Fight Human Trafficking) in front of 117 international delegations. Her song ''Not for Sale'' became the anthem of the anti-trafficking campaign.<ref>[http://blog.ruslana.ua/?language=en Ruslana Blog]</ref>
Within the frames of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2005]] in [[Kiev]] she gave a charity concert for children suffering from the consequences of the [[Chernobyl]] tragedy. For another charity project Ruslana joined forces with German rock star [[Peter Maffay]].<ref>[http://www.maffay.de/begegnungen/ Website of Peter Maffay] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311082622/http://www.maffay.de/begegnungen |date=11 March 2010 }}</ref> In April/May 2007 they went together with artists from 14 countries on a four weeks tour through Germany. The funds gathered benefited children in need.
Ruslana has also staged numerous charity concerts benefiting Children's hospitals in [[Kiev]], [[Lviv]] and [[Dnipropetrovsk]].
With her project Wild Energy Ruslana supports the use of [[renewable energy]]. She regards the energy of the sun, the water and the wind as an energy independence. The project gradually developed into this bigger meaning. Ruslana wants to make people aware of the dangers of [[global climate change]].<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=89436819 A Ukrainian Pop Star's Would-Be Revolution]</ref>
After large regions in Western Ukraine were hit by a flood in July 2008 Ruslana set up the co-ordinating and relief centre ''Carpathians. Flood. SOS! 2008''. The aim of the centre is to create a database of the people in need, to provide emergency humanitarian help and to collect and distribute donations both from the public and from other Ukrainian artists and sportsmen to support the victims of the flood.<ref>[http://karpatysos.info/en/ Carpathians. Flood. SOS!]</ref>

'''Samūm''' ({{lang-ar|سموم}} also spelled ''Simoom'' or ''Semum''; from the root {{lang|ar|س م م}} ''s-m-m'', {{lang|ar|سم}} "to poison") is a [[Quran]]ic term referring to infernal heat and in Extra-Quranic accounts, also to a kind of [[demon]]. In {{Cite quran|56|42|s=ns}} the tormenting fires of [[Jahannam]] are called ''samūm'' and it is also mentioned in {{Cite quran|15|26|s=ns}} as the origin of [[Jann (legendary creature)|Jann]]. In non-Arabic Qur'anic translations, the term is often translated with "scorching fire" or "scorching winds", because apart from its Islamic usage, samūm also refers to a [[Simoom|hot, dusty desert wind]].<ref>John Penrice ''A Dictionary and Glossary of the Koran: With Grammatical References and Explanations of the Text'' Biblo & Tannen Publishers 1969 {{ISBN|978-0-819-60252-7}} page 72</ref><ref>Rashid al-Din ''Rashid al-Din's History of India: Collected Essays with Facsimiles and Indices'' Walter de Gruyter 1965 {{ISBN|978-3-111-71602-2}}</ref> Both terms may be [[Linguistics|linguistically]] related to [[Samael]]<ref>John Hamilton Warrack, John Warrack ''Carl Maria Von Weber'' CUP Archive 1976 {{ISBN|978-0-521-29121-7}} page 214</ref>, an [[Angel in Judaism|Archangel]] in [[Talmud]]ic and post-Talmudic literature, who envied humanity and in charge of destructive demons, similar to the Islamic legends about demons created from samūm, envying [[Adam in Islam|Adam]].
== Material of samūm == [[Tabari]] offers many interpretations for the nature of samūm. In one interpretation he provides, samūm is "hot wind which kills" and in another "the flame of the fire of the hot wind" and yet in another he relates it to "night-wind" in opposition to ''harur'' (day-wind). Further he states, some hold samūm to be the hell-fire (''nar jahannama''). On the authority of [[Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah|Abu Ubaidah]], samūm is the fire that "penetrates the pores due to its fineness in the day-time as well as at night". [[Abu Sãlih]] is reported as saying that samūm is ''smokeless fire'' located between the heavens and [[barzakh|the veil]]. According to [[Ibn Abbas]], the samūm is "the worst hot fire which kills". On the authority of [['Amir ibn Dinar]], samūm is the fire of the sun.<ref>Egdunas Racius ''ISLAMIC EXEGESIS ON THE JINN: THEIR ORIGIN, KINDS AND SUBSTANCE AND THEIR RELATION TO OTHER BEINGS '' pp. 133</ref> According to [[Ibn Kathir]], samūm is the "flame of the fire", which is "the best fire".
== Demon samūm == In one narration, the samūm is a sapient creature, which stayed loyal to [[God in Islam|God]] until the creation of [[Adam in Islam|Adam]]. Afterthat, they envied mankind and their ardor turned into hatred, therefore they were cast away from God's mercy. [[Satan#Islam|Satan]], who also disaproved the creation of mankind, became their leader and the samūms his most loyal servants.<ref>https://www.mailce.com/semum-nedir.html (turkish)</ref>
[[Tabari]] recorded a similar story authorized by [[Ibn Abbas]], that a pre-adamitic creature was once loyal to God and subordinative to [[Iblis]], and fought against the [[Jinn]]. But after God created humanity, they envied the new creation and became demons. However Tabari called these demons ''[[Hinn (mythology)|Hinn]]'' instead of "samūm". But depicted "samūm" as their origin in contrast to the Jinn, who were created from ''smokeless fire''.<ref>Mahmoud M. Ayoub ''The Qur'an and Its Interpreters: Surah 1 and 2'' Islamic Book Trust 2012 {{ISBN|978-9-675-06290-2}} page 74</ref>
Furthermore, some legends relate "samūm" to the mother of [[Shaitan|demons]], created by God as a wife for Iblis, after the latter was banished from [[Jannah|heaven]].<ref>Patrick Hughes, Thomas Patrick Hughes ''Dictionary of Islam'' Asian Educational Services 1995 {{ISBN|978-8-120-60672-2}} p. 137</ref>
The 2008 Turkish [[horror film]] [[Semum]] is about "samūm", allegedly based on different independently narrations about [[Demonic possession|possessed]] people, claiming to encountered a samūm.<ref>Gönül Dönmez-Colin ''The Routledge Dictionary of Turkish Cinema'' Routledge 2013 {{ISBN|978-1-317-93726-5}} page 130</ref>

{{Infobox Politician | name = Seán Garland | honorific-suffix = | nationality = [[Irish people|Irish]] | image = garlands.jpg | office = [[Workers' Party of Ireland|General Secretary of the Workers' Party]] (Ireland) | term_start = 1977 | term_end = 1990 | predecessor = [[Máirín de Burca]] and [[Seán Ó Cionnaith]] (joint tenure) | successor = [[Des Geraghty]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1934|3|7|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | death_date = | death_place = }}
'''Seán Garland''' (born 7 March 1934) is a former President of the [[Workers' Party of Ireland|Workers' Party]] in Ireland.
==Early life== Born at Belvedere Place, off [[Mountjoy Square]] in [[Dublin]], Garland joined the [[Irish Republican Army (1922-1969)|Irish Republican Army]] in 1953. In 1954, he briefly joined the [[British Army]] as an IRA agent and collected intelligence on [[Gough Barracks]] in [[Armagh]] and supplied it to the IRA in [[Dublin]].<ref name="Hanley and Miller, p. 9">Hanley and Miller, p. 9</ref> This enabled the IRA to carry out a successful arms raid on 12 June 1954, with Garland's active involvement on the base. Garland deserted from the British army in October of the same year, before his regiment was due to depart for [[Kenya]].<ref name="Hanley and Miller, p. 9"/> He became a full-time IRA training officer.
On 1 January 1957 at the beginning of the IRA [[Border Campaign (IRA)|Border Campaign]], he led the unsuccessful attack on [[Brookeborough]] [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] barracks in which his associates [[Seán South]] and [[Fergal O'Hanlon]], both the subjects of well-known [[Irish republicanism|republican]] [[ballad]]s, were shot and fatally wounded. Under fire, Garland carried South on his shoulders in an unsuccessful attempt to save his friend's life. Seriously wounded, he was subsequently hospitalised for a number of weeks and was then jailed in [[Mountjoy Prison]]. In November 1957, while in Mountjoy, Garland was an unsuccessful candidate in the [[Dublin North-Central (Dáil constituency)|Dublin North-Central]] by-election. Upon his release, he was [[interned]] in the [[Curragh]], but was released in 1959.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workerspartyireland.net/history.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018215010/http://www.workerspartyireland.net/history.html |archivedate=18 October 2008 |df= }} Interview with Garland on Downtown Radio, August 2007</ref>
Garland returned to IRA service on his release and was sent to [[Belfast]] to liaise with the then largely inactive units in the city. He was arrested while trying to return to Dublin and sentenced in November 1959 to four years in [[Crumlin Road Gaol]] where he subsequently became officer commanding (O.C.) of the IRA prisoners.<ref>[http://www.workerspartyireland.net/history.html Workers Party website containing interview with Seán Garland on Downtown Radio in August 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018215010/http://www.workerspartyireland.net/history.html |date=18 October 2008 }}</ref><ref>Hanley and Miller, p. 18</ref>
==From Sinn Féin to the Workers' Party of Ireland== In the 1960s, Garland became a [[Marxist]] and was one of a generation of IRA leaders who attempted to lead the organisation away from violence and into left-wing political agitation. He worked closely in this with figures such as [[Cathal Goulding]] and [[Tomás MacGiolla]]. During the 1969/70 IRA split, Garland supported the moves to abandon [[abstentionism]] and was a key figure in [[Official Sinn Féin]] (as national organiser) and [[Official Irish Republican Army]] (as Adjutant-General). The Official IRA was openly involved in shootings and bombings of military and civilian targets but declared a [[ceasefire]] in May 1972. Despite this, the Official IRA continued to carry out shootings and robberies during the 1970s and was engaged in a number of feuds with the [[Provisional IRA]] and the [[Irish National Liberation Army]] (INLA).
On 1 March 1975 in [[Ballymun]], Dublin, Garland survived an INLA assassination attempt while returning home with his wife Mary to his Ballymun home. He was badly wounded in the attack. In 1977, Garland was elected general secretary of Official Sinn Féin. In the same year, he successfully proposed that the party be renamed [[Sinn Féin the Workers Party]]. In 1982, he proposed that the prefix Sinn Féin be dropped from the party name to become simply [[Workers' Party of Ireland|The Workers' Party]]. {{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}
In 1999 Garland was allegedly observed visiting the [[North Korea]]n embassy in [[Moscow]]. It was subsequently alleged that he visited to collect forged [[Superdollar|US dollars]] which, with the help of associates, would be transported to [[Dublin]] and [[Birmingham]] where the notes would be exchanged for [[Pound sterling|pounds]] or authentic dollars.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4337610.stm|work=BBC News|title=US says North Korea forged dollars|date=13 October 2005|accessdate=24 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/dc/Press_Releases/2005_Archives/Oct_2005/05370.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051014220354/http://www.justice.gov/usao/dc/Press_Releases/2005_Archives/Oct_2005/05370.html |archivedate=14 October 2005 |df= }}</ref> The US authorities announced that this scheme, which they said involved several international crime syndicates and transactions worth millions of dollars, had been uncovered in "Operation Mali".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/workers-party-boss-linked-to-counterfeit-super-dollars-503002.html | work=Irish Independent | first=Willie | last=Kealy | title=Workers' Party boss linked to counterfeit 'super dollars' | date=18 August 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/city_banks_target_of_fake_dollars_fraud_1_324175|title=City banks target of fake dollars fraud|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.detecting.org.uk/html/Super_Dollar_Famous_Fakes_and_Frauds.html|title=The Super Dollar Famous Fakes and Frauds|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref>
Seán Garland was the Workers' Party representative at the [[National Forum on Europe]]. In 2000, he was elected president of the Workers' Party.
==Involvement with KGB==
In 1988 Sean Garland asked the [[KGB]] to provide "special training" to up to five members of the [[Workers' Party of Ireland|Workers' Party]] in order to improve party security. This request was made through the KGB station chief in Dublin, with whom Sean Garland had "confidential contacts". The head of the KGB, [[Vladimir Kryuchkov]], viewed the request positively. However, on 12 January 1989, the International Department of the Central Committee of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] turned it down, fearing that leaked news of such cooperation would damage the Soviet relationship with the United Kingdom.<ref>[https://bukovskyarchive.wordpress.com/2016/07/06/06-january-1989-no-number/ The Bukovsky Archives, 6 January 1989*.]</ref> Copies of Kryuchkov's letter and of the Central Committee decision can be found in an archive of classified documents smuggled out of Russia by [[Vladimir Bukovsky]].
==Extradition fight== [[File:MacGiolla Garland.jpg|300px|thumb|Seán Garland (right) with Tomás MacGiolla, May 2008]]
On 7 October 2005, Garland was arrested in [[Belfast]] on foot of an [[extradition]] application issued by the US authorities. He had been attending the Workers' Party [[Ardfheis]]/Annual Conference at the time. The [[United States of America|United States]] authorities alleged that Garland had been involved in the distribution and resale of [[Counterfeit money|counterfeited]] US dollars - so-called "[[superdollar]]s" or "supernotes" - in 1998. They also alleged that the source of the banknotes was the government of [[North Korea]].<ref name=doj-20051008>{{cite press release |url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/dc/Press_Releases/2005_Archives/Oct_2005/05370.html |title=Leader of Irish Workers' Party and Official Irish Republican Army Leader of Irish Workers' Party and Official Irish Republican Army Arrested in United Kingdom on U.S. Indictment Charging Trafficking in Counterfeit United States Currency |publisher=U.S. Department of Justice |date=8 October 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051014220354/http://www.justice.gov/usao/dc/Press_Releases/2005_Archives/Oct_2005/05370.html |archivedate=2005-10-14}}</ref><ref>BBC [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4337610.stm US says N Korea forged dollars] 13 October 2005</ref> Garland was released on [[bail]].
A campaign was then launched against the US extradition attempt.<ref>[http://www.seangarland.org Seán Garland's official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051219212232/http://www.seangarland.org/ |date=19 December 2005 }}</ref> His supporters claimed the U.S. waited for Garland to travel north of the Irish border before seeking his extradition, believing the [[United Kingdom]] authorities would be more willing to acquiesce than those in the [[Republic of Ireland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seangarland.org/id5.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071130234448/http://www.seangarland.org/id5.html |archivedate=30 November 2007 |df= }} briefing No.1 point 5</ref> In June 2007 the Irish edition of the [[Mail on Sunday]] speculated that there was evidence that the affair was a US plot to provide a pretext for a military attack on North Korea <ref>Irish Mail on Sunday, 24 June 2007</ref>
On 9 October 2005, a ''Sunday Times'' article alleged that Garland became [[List of IRA Chiefs of Staff|chief of staff]] of the largely inactive Official IRA in 1998.<ref>Liam Clarke [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2091-1817418,00.html Garland arrested in US forgery hunt] 9 October 2005</ref>
On 1 December, the High Court in Belfast issued a warrant for Garland's arrest after he failed to appear for an extradition hearing. On 1 April 2006, Garland was unanimously re-elected as President of The Workers' Party and in a keynote address to the party membership gathered in Dublin he vowed to fight any attempt to extradite him to the United States. In 2008 he announced his intention to retire from the presidency and was replaced in the position on 17 May 2008 by [[Mick Finnegan]]. Garland remained a member of the party's Central Executive Committee and was its National Treasurer.<ref>[http://www.workerspartyireland.net/id163.html Workers' Party elect new Party President] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819180801/http://workerspartyireland.net/id163.html |date=19 August 2008 }}</ref>
Garland was subsequently arrested in Dublin in 2009 and the application by the U.S. to extradite him was heard in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0718/garlands.html|title=Garland accused in counterfeit notes plot|date=18 July 2011|work=RTÉ.ie|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref>
The campaign against his extradition continued, bringing in a number of prominent individuals from outside the Workers' Party including its Honorary Chairman the Rev. [[Chris Hudson (trade unionist)|Chris Hudson]]. It sought and received support from numerous political figures from across the spectrum in Ireland, the United Kingdom and further afield. Among these were dozens of members of the Oireachtas (Irish Parliament), MEPs and local politicians. Garland also received support from the entertainment industry including musicians [[Pete Seeger]], [[Christy Moore]], [[Alabama 3]] and [[John Spillane]]. Garland's supporters pointed out that the 77-year-old had been diagnosed from a number of serious medical conditions including diabetes and bowel cancer.<ref>[http://www.seangarland.org/seanad.html Health ailments of Seán Garland] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704183710/http://www.seangarland.org/seanad.html |date= 4 July 2010 }}</ref>
On 21 December 2011, Justice John Edwards in the High Court dismissed the US application for Garland's extradition. Justice Edwards told the court he was not disposed to grant the application and would furnish his reasons for doing so later.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/courts/garland-delighted-as-extradition-to-us-denied-2971087.html | work=Irish Independent | first=Brian | last=Kavanagh | title=Garland 'delighted' as extradition to US denied | date=22 December 2011}}</ref>
On 27 January 2012, Justice Edwards stated that since the offence for which the US wanted to extradite was regarded as having been committed in Ireland the Court was prohibited from extraditing Garland. He was therefore obliged to refer the case to the Director of Public Prosecutions who would consider whether there was a case for prosecuting Garland in Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/dpp-to-examine-whether-garland-should-be-prosecuted-in-ireland-338932-Jan2012/|title=DPP to examine whether Garland should be prosecuted in Ireland|author=Gavan Reilly|work=TheJournal.ie|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref>
On 29 May 2012, Garland spoke at the funeral of his comrade Noel Cullen, alongside Cullen's son Jake. Noel Cullen was a key figure in The Workers Party who died of cancer at the age of 52. Garland spoke on his friends passion, humanity, and quest for knowledge before handing Jake and Noel's daughter Ríona a starry plough, and an Irish flag. {{Citation needed |date=February 2016}}

[[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign]] ([[Master of Science|M.Sc.]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]]) |religion = [[Islam]] |signature = Sign Sri Mulyani.png }} '''Sri Mulyani Indrawati''' (born 26 August 1962) is an Indonesian economist who has been [[Minister of Finance (Indonesia)|Minister of Finance]] of [[Indonesia]] since 2016; previously she served in the same post from 2005 to 2010. In June 2010 she was appointed as Managing Director of the [[World Bank Group]] and resigned as Minister of Finance. ==Early life== Sri Mulyani was born in Tanjung Karang (now called [[Bandar Lampung]]) in [[Lampung]], [[Sumatra]], on August 26, 1962. She is the seventh child of university lecturers [[professor|Prof.]] Satmoko and Retno {{Not a typo|Sriningsih}}. She obtained her degree from [[Universitas Indonesia]] in 1986. Sri Mulyani received her master and doctorate in economics from the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] in 1992. In 2001, Mulyani left for [[Atlanta, Georgia]], to serve as a consultant with the US Agency for International Development ([[USAID]]) for programs to strengthen Indonesia’s autonomy. She also lectured on the Indonesian economy as visiting professor at the [[Andrew Young School of Policy Studies]] at the [[Georgia State University]].{{Cite web |title = Who's Who |publisher = The Jakarta Post |location = Jakarta |url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/directory/whos_who/S |accessdate = May 13, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100224034932/http://www.thejakartapost.com/directory/whos_who/S |archivedate = February 24, 2010 |df = }} From 2002 to 2004 she was an executive director on the board of the [[International Monetary Fund]] representing 12 economies in Southeast Asia. She is married to economist Tony Sumartono, with whom she has three children.{{Cite news | title = Sri Mulyani Ekonom Pasar Yang Kian Mapan | newspaper = Berita Sore | date = October 22, 2009 | url = http://beritasore.com/2009/10/22/sri-mulyani-ekonom-pasar-yang-kian-mapan/ }}{{Cite news |title = Keluarga Menkeu Sri Mulyani di Tengah Terpaan Kasus Century |newspaper = Jawa Pos |location = Surabaya |date = December 15, 2009 |url = http://www.jawapos.com/halaman/index.php?act=detail&nid=105637 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030813/http://www.jawapos.com/halaman/index.php?act=detail&nid=105637 |archivedate = March 4, 2016 |df = }} She is a professional economist and has no political affiliation.{{Cite news | title = Indonesia reels from corruption fighter's departure for World Bank | first = Tom | last = Allard | newspaper = Sidney Morning Herald | url = http://www.smh.com.au/world/indonesia-reels-from-corruption-fighters-departure-for-world-bank-20100505-uaon.html | date = May 6, 2010}} ==As finance minister== Sri Mulyani was selected as Indonesian Finance Minister in 2005 by President [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]]. One of her first acts was to fire corrupt tax and custom officers in the department. She successfully tackled [[political corruption|corruption]] and initiated reforms in Indonesia's tax and customs office{{Cite news |title = Sri Mulyani dan Modernisasi Pajak |first = Chandra |last = Budi |newspaper = Jawa Pos |location = Surabaya |date = May 6, 2010 |url = http://www.jawapos.com/halaman/index.php?act=detail&nid=132269 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161023140947/http://www.jawapos.com/halaman/index.php?act=detail&nid=132269 |archivedate = October 23, 2016 |df = }} and enjoys a reputation for integrity.{{Cite news|title= United Indonesia Cabinet 2009–2014|newspaper= [[The Jakarta Post]] | location = Jakarta |date= 2009-10-22|page= 3}} She succeeded in increasing direct investment in Indonesia. In 2004, the year President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono took office, Indonesia received $4.6 billion in foreign direct investment. The next year, it attracted $8.9 billion.{{Cite news | title = A Reformer Leaves Jakarta | newspaper = Wall Street Journal | date = May 13, 2010 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703880304575237233920187228?mod=WSJ_latestheadlines#articleTabs%3Darticle }} In 2006, just one year after selected, she was named [[Euromoney Finance Minister of the Year]] by ''[[Euromoney]]'' magazine.{{Cite news | title = Minister of Finance of the year 2006: Dr Sri Mulyani Indrawati | first = Christ | last = Leahy | newspaper = Euromoney | date = September 2006 | url = http://www.euromoney.com/Article/1079138/Title.html?Type=Article&ArticleID=1079138 }} During her tenure in 2007, Indonesia recorded 6.6% economic growth, its highest rate since the [[1997 Asian financial crisis]]. However, growth is down in 2008 to 6% due to [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010|the global economic slowdown]]. In July 2008, Sri Mulyani Indrawati was inaugurated as the Coordinating Minister for the economy, replacing [[Boediono]], who was to head the [[Bank Indonesia|central bank]].{{Cite news | title = Sri Mulyani named coordinating minister | newspaper = The Jakarta Post | location = Jakarta | date = July 6, 2008 | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/06/25/sri-mulyani-named-coordinating-minister.html}} In August 2008, Mulyani was ranked by ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine as the 23rd most powerful woman in the world{{Cite news | title = The 100 Most Powerful Women – #23 Sri Mulyani Indrawati | work = Forbes | date = August 27, 2008 | url = https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/11/biz_powerwomen08_Sri-Mulyani-Indrawati_VW20.html | accessdate = }} and the most powerful woman in Indonesia. During her tenure as Finance Minister, the country's foreign exchange reserves reached an all-time high of $50 billion. She oversaw a reduction in public debt to about 30% of [[gross domestic product]] from 60%, making it easier for Indonesia to sell debt to foreign institutional investors. She also revised incentive structures for civil servants in her ministry and began paying higher salaries to tax officials deemed to be "clean" so they would have less temptation to accept bribes.{{Cite news | last = Barta | first = Patrick | title = Reformer Resigns, Rattling Indonesia | newspaper = Wall Street Journal | date = May 6, 2010 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703866704575225262408521190?KEYWORDS=Sri+Mulyani }} In 2007 and 2008, ''Emerging Markets'' newspaper selected Sri Mulyani as [[Asia]]'s Finance Minister of The Year.{{Cite news |title = Mulyani, Asia's best finance minister two years in a row |newspaper = The Jakarta Post |location = Jakarta |date = October 14, 2009 |url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/10/14/mulyani-asia039s-best-finance-minister-two-years-a-row.html |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100325224855/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/10/14/mulyani-asia039s-best-finance-minister-two-years-a-row.html |archivedate = March 25, 2010 |df = }} {{Cite news |first = Nick |last = Parson |title = Finance Minister of The Year, Asia 2008 |newspaper = Emerging Markets |date = October 10, 2008 |url = http://www.emergingmarkets.org/article.asp?PositionID=search&ArticleID=2272185 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160307142124/http://www.emergingmarkets.org/article.asp?articleid=2272185&positionid=search |archivedate = March 7, 2016 |df = }} [[File:Indrawati, Sri Mulyani (IMF).jpg|thumb|150px|Sri Mulyani as Managing Director of the World Bank Group (2010)]] After Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono [[Indonesian presidential election, 2009|was re-elected in 2009]], she was re-appointed in her post of Finance Minister. In 2009 the Indonesian economy grew up by 4.5% while [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010|many part of the world is in recession]]. Indonesia is one of just three major emerging economies to grow faster than 4% in 2009. The other two are China and India. Under her supervision, government has managed to increase the number of [[income tax]]payers from 4.35 million individuals to nearly 16 million in the last five years, and tax receipts grew by around 20% each year to more than Rp 600 trillion in 2010.{{Cite news | last = Bayuni | first = Endy M. | title = Commentary: Wanted: Big Foot for finance minister | newspaper = The Jakarta Post | location = Jakarta | date = May 14, 2010 | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/05/14/commentary-wanted-big-foot-finance-minister.html }} ===Alleged hacking by Australian intelligence=== In November 2013, British newspaper [[The Guardian]] published article with report from leaks by [[Edward Snowden]], showing that Australian intelligence had allegedly hacked into mobile phones of top Indonesian leaders in 2009. This included Sri Mulyani which at that time was the minister of finance.{{Citation | date = 18 November 2013 | title = Revealed: Australia tried to monitor Indonesian president's phone | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/18/australia-tried-to-monitor-indonesian-presidents-phone }} Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended it by saying that the Critics of the bailout claim it was done without legal authority and without proving a capital injection was needed to prevent a run on other banks, Bank Century bailout cost the state to suffer a financial lost amounting to 6.7 trillion rupiah ($710 million).{{Cite news | title = KPK Investigate Two of Nine Criminal Indications on Bank Century Case | newspaper = Hukumonline English | date = November 29, 2010 | url = http://en.hukumonline.com/pages/lt4cf3bab27720c/kpk-investigate-two-of-nine-criminal-indications-on-bank-century-case }} Sri Mulyani has defended the bailout as necessary given the uncertainties in the global economy at the time and denied any wrongdoing. However, criticism about Sri Mulyani's policy also came from ex [[Vice President of Indonesia|vice president]] [[Jusuf Kalla]]. In his harshest comments yet on the controversial PT Bank Century bailout, former Vice President Jusuf Kalla denied claims by former Bank Indonesia officials that if the lender had been allowed to fail it would have had a systemic impact on the country’s banking system and economy. “The Bank Century scandal is a robbery, anyone who supports Bank Century, supports a robber.” Kalla said.{{Cite news |title = Ex-Indonesian Vice President Kalla Calls Century Scandal ‘Robbery’ |newspaper = The Jakarta Globe |location = Jakarta |date = May 19, 2010 |url = http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/ex-indonesian-vice-president-kalla-calls-century-scandal-robbery/351709 |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130203233558/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/ex-indonesian-vice-president-kalla-calls-century-scandal-robbery/351709 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = February 3, 2013 }} Furthermore, all of the nine factions on the House of Representatives special committee agreed that there were suspicious and possibly fraudulent transactions during the bailout period beginning in November 2008 and evidence of money laundering.
